['', '', 'Customer Focus \xa0 Every product we make and every service we provide is for our customers. Focus on providing innovative, high-quality products and services and on demonstrating integrity in every business interaction. Always apply\nApple\x92s principles of business conduct.']
['', '']
['To what extent may I use an existing customer list to market other Apple products or services?\nBefore using a customer list for marketing, sales, or other activities, talk to your manager or the Legal Department. Using an existing customer list may or may not\nbe appropriate.', '', 'Customer and Third-Party Information \xa0\nCustomers, suppliers, and others disclose confidential information to Apple for business purposes. It is the responsibility of every Apple employee to protect and\nmaintain the confidentiality of this information. Failure to protect customer and third-party information may damage relations with customers, suppliers, or others and may result in legal liability. See the Apple Customer Privacy\nPolicy.']
['', '']
['Where can I learn more about information protection and nondisclosure agreements? View the Apple policy on Confidential, Proprietary, and Trade Secret Information. \xa0 Where can I get a nondisclosure agreement? In the U.S., see the forms Apple provides for nondisclosure\nagreements. Outside the U.S., consult your local Apple Legal representative.', '', 'Nondisclosure Agreements \xa0\nWhen dealing with a supplier, vendor, or other third party, never share confidential information without your manager\x92s approval. Also, never share\nconfidential information outside Apple (for example, with vendors, suppliers, or others) unless a nondisclosure agreement is in place. These agreements document the need to maintain the confidentiality of the information. Original copies of\nnondisclosure agreements must be forwarded to the Legal Department. Always limit the amount of confidential information shared to the minimum necessary to address the business need.']
['', '']
['As long as the information helps Apple, why is the source of business intelligence an issue?\nObtaining information illegally or unethically could damage Apple\x92s reputation and in some cases could subject Apple to legal liability. For example, using\nillegally or unethically obtained information in a bid to the government could result in disqualification from future bidding and in criminal charges.', '', 'Obtaining and Using Business Intelligence \xa0\nApple legitimately collects information on customers and markets in which we operate. Apple does not seek business intelligence by illegal or unethical means, and\ncompetitors may not be contacted for the purpose of obtaining business intelligence. Sometimes information is obtained accidentally or is provided to Apple by unknown sources. In such cases, it may be unethical to use the information, and you should\nimmediately contact your manager, the Legal Department, or the Business Conduct Helpline to determine how to proceed.']
['', '']
['', '', 'Third-Party Intellectual Property \xa0\nIt is Apple\x92s policy not to knowingly use the intellectual property of any third party without permission or legal right. If you are told or suspect that Apple\nmay be infringing an intellectual property right, including patents, copyrights, trademarks, or trade secrets owned by a third party, you should contact the Legal Department.']
['', '']
['May I keep my personal music on my computer at work? If you are authorized to make copies of the music for personal use (for example, you own the original CD or you purchased the music on iTunes), you may keep the music on your computer.', '', 'Copyright-Protected Content \xa0\nNever use or copy software, music, videos, publications, or other copyright-protected content at work or for business purposes unless you or Apple are legally\npermitted to use or make copies of the protected content. Never use Apple facilities or equipment to make or store unauthorized copies.']

['Customer and\nBusiness Relationships', '', 'Business Conduct The way we do business\nworldwide July 2011', '', '5']

Table:
['', '', '']
['Are business meals, travel, and entertainment considered gifts? Yes. Anything of value given or received is considered a gift. \xa0 Can I avoid these rules if I pay for gifts to customers or business associates myself? No. If the gift is given\nfor business reasons and you are representing Apple, the gift rules apply.', '', 'Giving and Receiving Business Gifts \xa0\nEmployees may not give or receive gifts or entertainment to or from current or potential vendors, suppliers, customers, or other business associates unless all of\nthe following conditions are met: \xa0\n\x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Nominal value. The value of the gift is less than US$150. Exceptions must be\napproved by your Vice President (for Vice President\x96level employees, exceptions must be approved by your manager). \xa0\n\x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Customary. The item is a customary business gift and would not embarrass Apple\nif publicly disclosed. Cash is never an acceptable gift. Giving or receiving cash is viewed as a bribe or kickback and is always against Apple policy. \xa0\n\x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0No favored treatment. The purpose of the gift is not to obtain special or\nfavored treatment. \xa0\n\x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Legal. Giving or accepting the gift is legal in the location and under the\ncircumstances where given. \xa0\n\x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Recipient is not a government official. Never provide a gift, including meals,\nentertainment, or other items of value, to a U.S. or foreign government official without checking with Government Affairs in advance. See page 7 for more information on gifts to government officials.\n\xa0 This policy does not preclude Apple as an organization from receiving and evaluating\ncomplimentary products or services. It is not intended to preclude Apple from giving equipment to a company or organization, provided the gift is openly given, consistent with legal requirements, and in Apple\x92s business interests. The policy\nalso does not preclude the attendance of Apple employees at business-related social functions, if attendance is approved by management and does not create a conflict of interest.\n\xa0 Important Note: Certain departments (e.g., Operations and Retail) have more restrictive\ngift policies, which may prohibit giving or receiving gifts altogether. Employees in those departments must adhere to those stricter policies.']
['', '']
['What is an example of a kickback? Apple\nprovides discounts to certain customers. However, if a customer gets an inappropriate discount, and a sales representative gets a payment in return, this is a kickback. \xa0\nWhat is an example of a side deal? In a sales environment, a\nside deal may involve a guarantee to accept back unsold products or other special agreements to encourage certain customers to place larger orders. Such a side deal, whether written or oral, can impact Apple\x92s potential liability with respect\nto that transaction and may make it inappropriate for Apple to recognize revenue on the products sold, affecting the accuracy of Apple\x92s books and records. Side deals or side letters made outside of Apple\x92s formal contracting and approvals\nprocess are strictly prohibited.', '', 'Kickbacks \xa0 Kickbacks are payments or items of value given to individuals in connection with the purchase or sale of products or services, typically for providing a discount in a sales agreement. Employees are prohibited from\ngiving or receiving kickbacks. \xa0 Side Deals or Side Letters\n\xa0 All of the terms and conditions of agreements entered into by Apple must be formally\ndocumented. Contract terms and conditions define the key attributes of Apple\x92s rights, obligations, and liabilities and can also dictate the accounting treatment given to a transaction. Making business commitments outside of the formal\ncontracting process, through side deals, side letters, or otherwise, is unacceptable. You should not make any oral or written commitments that create a new agreement or modify an existing agreement without approval through the formal contracting\nprocess. In particular, all commitments must have visibility to Finance so Apple can ensure it is properly accounting for each transaction. If you have knowledge of any side deal, side letter, or agreement made outside of the formal contracting\nprocess, you should report it immediately to your manager, your Human Resources representative, or the Legal Department. You may also contact the Business Conduct Helpline.']

['What can I do if a reseller complains to me about low prices at another reseller? Advise the reseller that you can\x92t discuss or attempt to influence pricing of other parties, since this could violate antitrust laws.\n\xa0 How should I handle customer inquiries about resellers and service\nproviders? Apple resellers and service providers are key members of the Apple family. They promote and sell Apple products, and they provide service\nand support to Apple customers. Accordingly, you should never make disparaging remarks to customers about resellers or service providers.', '', 'Competition and Trade Practices \xa0\nLaws regulating competition and trade practices vary around the world, but certain activities, such as price fixing and agreeing with a competitor to allocate\ncustomers, are almost always illegal and are absolutely prohibited under Apple policy. \xa0 You should not: \xa0 \x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Agree with competitors or exchange information with competitors on prices, policies, contract terms, costs, inventories, marketing plans, or capacity plans.\n\xa0 \x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Agree with a\ncompetitor that the competitor will sell goods and services to Customer A (and you will not), and that you will sell goods and services to Customer B (and your competitor will not).\n\xa0 \x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Agree with\nresellers on the resale pricing of Apple products without Legal Department approval. \xa0\n\x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Require vendors to purchase Apple products in order to sell products or services to\nApple. \xa0\n\x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Describe the products or services of competitors inaccurately to promote Apple products\nor services. \xa0\n\x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Engage in any pricing or other practices that could defraud a supplier or\nothers. \xa0\n\x95\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0Violate fair bidding practices, including bidding quiet periods, or provide information\nto benefit one vendor over other vendors.']

['Tell me more about pricing products that are sold to governments.', '', 'Governments as Customers']
['Governments shouldn\x92t be charged more for our products or services than Apple charges other customers for the same products or services. There are laws that make it a crime to overcharge\nthe U.S. government. Some other countries have similar laws.', '', 'Governments are unique customers for Apple. Governments often place special bidding, pricing, disclosure, and certification requirements on firms with which they do business. Discuss these\nrequirements with Government Affairs or your local Apple Legal representative before bidding for government business. For example, Apple may have to certify that it is supplying the government with the lowest price charged to Apple\x92s commercial\ncustomers. Apple may also have to certify that its prices have been arrived at independently\x97that is, without collaboration with a third party.']

['Can I avoid a gift limitation by paying for a gift, such as lunch or golf, myself?', '', 'Gifts to U.S. Officials']
['No. If you are representing Apple, any gift to a government employee would be viewed as coming from Apple.\n\xa0 What is considered a gift to a U.S. or\nforeign official? In most cases, anything of value that is\ngiven is considered a gift. This includes items such as meals, golf, entertainment, and product samples. Cash is never an acceptable gift. Typically, giving cash is viewed as a bribe or kickback and is against Apple policy.\n\xa0 Who is considered a government official?\nAny official or employee of a government, a public international organization (such as the European Commission), any department or agency thereof, or any person\nacting in an official capacity. It can also include employees of a state-run or state-owned business, such as a public utility or university.', '', 'It may be illegal to give a gift, even an inexpensive meal or a T-shirt, to a government employee. The rules vary depending on the location and job position of the government employee (for\nexample, rules may vary by state, school district, and city, and there may be different rules for various elected and nonelected officials).']
['', 'To prevent violations, review planned gifts to government officials with\nGovernment Affairs in advance of giving a gift.']
['', 'Gifts to Non-U.S. Officials\n\xa0 In many countries it is considered common courtesy to provide token/ceremonial gifts to\ngovernment officials on certain occasions to help build relationships. Check local requirements and review any such gifts exceeding US$25 in advance with the Legal Department. For meals, the US$25 limit does not necessarily apply. Check here for\nvalue limits by country on meals to non-U.S. public officials and employees. Meals at any value should be avoided with officials from government agencies where Apple has a pending application, proposal, or other business.\n\xa0 No Bribery or Corruption\n\xa0 Offering or giving anything of value to a government official for the purpose of obtaining or\nretaining business or to secure any improper advantage is illegal. Apple personnel shall not offer or accept bribes or use other inappropriate means to obtain an undue or improper advantage, or otherwise violate U.S. or international anticorruption\nlaws and regulations (e.g., the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act).']
['', 'For additional information, see Apple\x92s Foreign Corrupt Practices Act\nPolicy.']
['', 'Political Contributions']
['', 'Apple contributes selectively to political candidates and committees. All\ncorporate political contributions, whether monetary or in-kind (such as the donation/lending of equipment or technical services to a campaign), must be approved in advance by Apple Government Affairs. Employees may not use Apple assets (including\nemployee work time, or use of Apple premises, equipment, or funds) to personally support candidates and campaigns. It is illegal for Apple to reimburse an employee for a contribution. For more information, see the Apple Corporate Political\nCompliance Policy and the Political Contributions and Expenditures Policy.']

['', '', '']
['Tell me more about \x93legal holds.\x94 In a litigation case or other legal matter, Apple may be required to produce documents. In these cases the Legal Department may put a \x93legal hold\x94 on certain documents to prevent the documents from being\ndestroyed, altered, or modified. If it is found that Apple has failed to retain or produce required documents, penalties or adverse rulings may result. Adverse rulings in major litigation cases can cost Apple a significant amount of money. Failure\nof employees to retain and preserve documents placed on a legal hold may result in discipline or discharge.', '', 'Document Retention and Legal Hold']
['', 'As an Apple employee, you have a responsibility to manage documents and make\ndecisions on document retention. The definition of \x93document\x94 is extremely broad. For example, every email or other electronic file, every customer record, and every transaction involves the creation of a document. Different documents have\ndifferent retention periods. Check with your manager or contact Records Management to determine the appropriate retention period for documents in your area. \xa0\nAt times, Apple may need to retain documents beyond the period they would normally be retained. The most common reasons are litigation or other legal matters. In\nthese situations, retention and preservation of documents is critical. If you have documents that may be required for litigation or other legal matters, the Legal Department will place those documents on a \x93legal hold,\x94 meaning the\ndocuments cannot be altered, destroyed, deleted, or modified in any manner. Legal will notify the individuals most closely identified with the documents about the legal hold and will provide instructions for retaining the documents. Recipients of a\nlegal hold must ensure that these instructions are followed. A legal hold remains in effect until you are notified by the Legal Department in writing.']

['I have stock in companies that do business with Apple. Is this a problem? It\x92s unlikely that this is a problem. However, it could be a concern if (1)\xa0you\x92re influencing a transaction between Apple and the company, and (2)\xa0the transaction is significant enough to\npotentially affect the value of your investment.', '', 'Personal Investments \xa0 Many Apple employees have investments in publicly traded stock or privately held businesses. These personal investments may give rise to a conflict of interest if you are involved in or attempt to influence\ntransactions between Apple and a business in which you are invested. If a real or apparent conflict arises, disclose the conflict to your manager. The manager will help determine whether a conflict exists and, if appropriate, the best approach to\neliminate the conflict. \xa0 Workplace Relationships\n\xa0 Personal relationships in the workplace may present an actual or perceived conflict of interest\nwhere one individual in the relationship may be in a position to make or influence employment decisions regarding the other. If you find yourself in such a relationship, you must notify Human Resources so they may assist you in resolving any\npotential conflicts. Employees should not allow their relationships to disrupt the workplace or interfere with their work or judgment. For additional information, see Apple\x92s policy on Personal Relationships.']
['', '']
['How do I know whether information is material? Determining what constitutes material information is a matter of judgment. In general, information is material if it would likely be considered important by an investor buying or selling the particular\nstock. \xa0 Does Apple\x92s policy apply to buying or selling stock in other\ncompanies? Yes. For example, say you learn about a customer\x92s nonpublic expansion plans through discussions about hardware purchases. If you\npurchase stock in the customer\x92s company or advise others to do so, it could be viewed as insider trading.', '', 'Buying and Selling Stock \xa0\nNever buy or sell stock while you are in possession of information obtained through your employment at Apple that has not been publicly announced and could have a\nmaterial effect on the value of the stock. This applies to decisions to buy or sell Apple securities and to investments in other companies. It is also against Apple policy and may be illegal to give others, such as friends and family, tips on when\nto buy or sell stock while you are in possession of material, nonpublic information concerning that stock. \xa0 In addition, employees are prohibited from investing in derivatives of Apple\x92s securities. This includes, but is not limited to, trading in put or call options related to securities of the company.\n\xa0 Members of Apple\x92s Board of Directors, executive officers, and certain other individuals\nare subject to blackout periods during which they are prohibited from trading in Apple stock. If you are subject to these restrictions, you will be notified by the Legal Department. Even if you are not subject to blackout periods, you may never buy\nor sell stock while you are in possession of material, nonpublic information. \xa0\nReview Apple\x92s Insider Trading policy. Specific questions on buying and selling stock should be referred to the Legal Department.']

['What is harassment? Harassment can be\nverbal, visual, or physical in nature. Specific examples of prohibited harassing conduct include, but are not limited to: slurs, jokes, statements, notes, letters, electronic communication, pictures, drawings, posters, cartoons, gestures, and\nunwelcome physical contact that are based on an individual\x92s protected class. \xa0\nNeed more information? In the U.S., refer to Apple\x92s\nHarassment policy. Outside the U.S., contact Human Resources.', '', 'Harassment and Discrimination \xa0\nApple encourages a creative, culturally diverse, and supportive work environment. Apple does not tolerate harassment or discrimination based on factors such as\nrace, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity characteristics or expression, religion, national origin, age, marital status, disability, medical condition, veteran status, or pregnancy. Additional restrictions may apply based on regional\nlaws and regulations. \xa0 These requirements apply to interactions with employees,\ncustomers, suppliers, and applicants for employment and any other interactions where you represent Apple. \xa0 If you feel that you have been harassed or discriminated against or have witnessed such behavior, report the situation to a manager or to Human Resources. You may also contact the Business Conduct\nHelpline.']

['If I make a presentation on my own time, may I accept a payment?', '', 'Public Speaking and Press Inquiries']

Before accepting\nthis type of opportunity, check with your manager, Human Resources, or the Business Conduct Helpline.', '', 'All public speaking engagements that relate to Apple\x92s business or products must be preapproved by your manager and Corporate Communications. If you receive approval to make a public\npresentation at a business meeting or conference, you may not request or accept any form of personal compensation from the organization that requested the presentation. This does not prohibit accepting reimbursement for expenses, if approved by your\nmanager.']

['', '', '']
['', '', 'Your Obligation to Take Action \xa0\nAlways apply Apple\x92s principles of business conduct, follow Apple policies, and comply with laws and regulations. When you are unsure, take the initiative to\ninvestigate the right course of action. Check with your manager, Human Resources, Legal, Internal Audit, or Finance, and review our policies on AppleWeb. If you would like to talk with someone outside your immediate area, consider contacting the\nBusiness Conduct Helpline. \xa0 If you know about a possible violation of Apple\x92s\nBusiness Conduct Policy or legal or regulatory requirements, you are required to notify your manager (provided your manager is not involved in the violation), Human Resources, Legal, Internal Audit, Finance, or the Business Conduct Helpline. Failure\nto do so may result in disciplinary action. \xa0 Employees must cooperate fully in any\nApple investigation and must keep their knowledge and participation confidential to help safeguard the integrity of the investigation. \xa0\nBusiness Conduct Helpline \xa0 The Business Conduct Helpline is available 24/7 to all employees worldwide to help answer your questions on business conduct issues, policies, regulations, and compliance with legal requirements. It also allows you\nto advise Apple of situations that may require investigation or management attention. \xa0\nThe Business Conduct Helpline is committed to keeping your issues and identity confidential. If you would be more comfortable doing so, you may contact the Helpline\nanonymously. Your information will be shared only with those who have a need to know, such as those involved in answering your questions or investigating and correcting issues you raise. Note that if your information involves accounting, finance, or\nauditing, the law may require that necessary information be shared with the Audit and Finance Committee of Apple\x92s Board of Directors. \xa0\nDue to legal restrictions, anonymous use of the Business Conduct Helpline is not encouraged in certain countries (e.g., France).\n\xa0 Apple will not retaliate\x97and will not tolerate retaliation\x97against any individual\nfor their good-faith use of the Business Conduct Helpline. \xa0 Information on\ncontacting the Business Conduct Helpline\x97including via email, toll-free telephone, and web access\x97is available on AppleWeb.']

["- DefinitionInvestments in debt and equity securities which are categorized neither as trading securities nor held-to-maturity securities and which are intended be sold or mature within one year from the balance sheet date or the normal operating cycle, whichever is longer. Such securities are reported at fair value; unrealized gains (losses) related to Available-for-sale Securities are excluded from earnings and reported in a separate component of shareholders' equity (other comprehensive income), unless the Available-for-sale security is designated as a hedge or is determined to have had an other than temporary decline in fair value below its amortized cost basis. All or a portion of the unrealized holding gain (loss) of an Available-for-sale security that is designated as being hedged in a fair value hedge is recognized in earnings during the period of the hedge, as are other than temporary declines in fair value below the cost basis for investments in equity securities and debt securities that an entity intends to sell or it is more likely than not that it will be required to sell before the recovery of its amortized cost basis. Other than temporary declines in fair value below the cost basis for debt securities categorized as Available-for-sale that an entity does not intend to sell and for which it is not more likely than not that the entity will be required to sell before the recovery of its amortized cost basis are bifurcated into credit losses and losses related to all other factors. Other than temporary declines in fair value below cost basis related to credit losses are recognized in earnings, and losses related to all other factors are recognized in other comprehensive income.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 320 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 2 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6871852&loc=d3e26626-111562Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 133 -Paragraph 22 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ["- DefinitionInvestments in debt and equity securities which are categorized neither as held-to-maturity nor trading and which are intended to be sold or mature more than one year from the balance sheet date or operating cycle, if longer. All or a portion of the unrealized holding gain (loss) of an Available-for-sale security that is designated as being hedged in a fair value hedge is recognized in earnings during the period of the hedge, as are other than temporary declines in fair value below the cost basis for investments in equity securities and debt securities that an entity intends to sell or it is more likely than not that it will be required to sell before the recovery of its amortized cost basis. ["- DefinitionIncludes currency on hand as well as demand deposits with banks or financial institutions. It also includes other kinds of accounts that have the general characteristics of demand deposits in that the Entity may deposit additional funds at any time and also effectively may withdraw funds at any time without prior notice or penalty. Cash equivalents, excluding items classified as marketable securities, include short-term, highly liquid investments that are both readily convertible to known amounts of cash, and so near their maturity that they present minimal risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates. Generally, only investments with original maturities of three months or less qualify under that definition. Original maturity means original maturity to the entity holding the investment. For example, both a three-month US Treasury bill and a three-year Treasury note purchased three months from maturity qualify as cash equivalents. However, a Treasury note purchased three years ago does not become a cash equivalent when its remaining maturity is three months. Compensating balance arrangements that do not legally restrict the withdrawal or usage of cash amounts may be reported as Cash and Cash Equivalents, while legally restricted deposits held as compensating balances against borrowing arrangements, contracts entered into with others, or company statements of intention with regard to particular deposits are not generally reported as cash and cash equivalents. Includes cash and cash equivalents associated with the entity's continuing operations. Excludes cash and cash equivalents associated with the disposal group (and discontinued operation).+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 210 -SubTopic 10 -Section S99 -Paragraph 1 -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02.1) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6877327&loc=d3e13212-122682Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher SEC -Name Regulation S-X (SX) -Number 210 -Section 02 -Paragraph 1 -Article 5Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 95 -Paragraph 7 -Footnote 1 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ["- DefinitionRepresents the caption on the face of the balance sheet to indicate that the entity has entered into (1) purchase or supply arrangements that will require expending a portion of its contract terms, and (b) possible losses or likely gains from uncertainties that will ultimately be resolved when one or more future events that are deemed likely to occur do occur or fail to occur.+ ["- DefinitionAggregate par or stated value of issued nonredeemable common stock (or common stock redeemable solely at the option of the issuer). ['- DefinitionThe noncurrent portion of deferred revenue amount as of balance sheet date. Deferred revenue is a liability related to a revenue producing activity for which revenue has not yet been recognized, and is not expected to be recognized in the next twelve months. Generally, an entity records deferred revenue when it receives consideration from a customer before achieving certain criteria that must be met for revenue to be recognized in conformity with GAAP.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 605 -SubTopic 10 -Section S99 -Paragraph 1 -Subparagraph (SAB TOPIC 13.A.4(a).Q1) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6600647&loc=d3e214044-122780Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 210 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 8 -Subparagraph (b) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6361293&loc=d3e6935-107765Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher AICPA -Name Accounting Research Bulletin (ARB) -Number 43 -Chapter 3 -Section A -Paragraph 7, 8 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['- DefinitionThe current portion of the aggregate tax effects as of the balance sheet date of all future tax deductions arising from temporary differences between tax basis and generally accepted accounting principles basis recognition of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses, which can only be deducted for tax purposes when permitted under enacted tax laws; after deducting the allocated valuation allowance, if any, to reduce such amount to net realizable value. Deferred tax liabilities and assets are classified as current or noncurrent based on the classification of the related asset or liability for financial reporting. A deferred tax liability or asset that is not related to an asset or liability for financial reporting, including deferred tax assets related to carryforwards, are classified according to the expected reversal date of the temporary difference. An unrecognized tax benefit that is directly related to a position taken in a tax year that results in a net operating loss carryforward is presented as a reduction of the related deferred tax asset.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 740 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 2 -Subparagraph (b) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6907707&loc=d3e32537-109319Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 740 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 5 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6907571&loc=d3e31928-109318Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 109 -Paragraph 41, 42, 43 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ["Shareholders' Equity and Share-based Compensation", '12 Months Ended']
['Sep. 24, 2011']
["Shareholders' Equity and Share-based Compensation", 'Note 6 –\nShareholders’ Equity and Share-based\nCompensation\nPreferred\nStock\n\nThe Company has\nfive million shares of authorized preferred stock, none of which is\nissued or outstanding. Under the terms of the Company’s\nRestated Articles of Incorporation, the Board of Directors is\nauthorized to determine or alter the rights, preferences,\nprivileges and restrictions of the Company’s authorized but\nunissued shares of preferred stock.\nComprehensive\nIncome\n\nComprehensive\nincome consists of two components, net income and other\ncomprehensive income. Other comprehensive income refers to revenue,\nexpenses, gains and losses that under GAAP are recorded as an\nelement of shareholders’ equity but are excluded from net\nincome. The Company’s other comprehensive income consists of\nforeign currency translation adjustments from those subsidiaries\nnot using the U.S. dollar as their functional currency, unrealized\ngains and losses on marketable securities classified as\navailable-for-sale, and net deferred gains and losses on certain\nderivative instruments accounted for as cash flow\nhedges.\n\nThe following\ntable summarizes the components of AOCI, net of taxes, as of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, September\xa025, 2010, and\nSeptember\xa026, 2009\xa0(in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2009\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nNet unrealized gains/losses\non marketable securities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0130\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0171\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa048\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nNet unrecognized\ngains/losses on derivative instruments\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n290\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(252\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n1\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCumulative foreign currency\ntranslation\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n23\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n35\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n28\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nAccumulated other\ncomprehensive income/(loss)\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n443\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(46\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n77\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nThe change in\nfair value of available-for-sale securities included in other\ncomprehensive income was $(41) million, $123 million and $118\nmillion, net of taxes in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively. The tax\neffect related to the change in unrealized gains/losses on\navailable-for-sale securities was $24 million, $(72) million and\n$(78) million for 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.\n\nThe following\ntable summarizes activity in other comprehensive income related to\nderivatives, net of taxes, held by the Company during the three\nyears ended September\xa024, 2011 (in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2009\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nChanges in fair value of\nderivatives\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa092\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0(180\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0204\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nAdjustment for net\ngains/losses realized and included in net income\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n450\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(73\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(222\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nChange in unrecognized\ngains/losses on derivative instruments\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n542\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(253\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(18\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nThe tax effect\nrelated to the changes in fair value of derivatives was $(50)\nmillion, $97 million and $(135) million for 2011, 2010 and 2009,\nrespectively. The tax effect related to derivative gains/losses\nreclassified from other comprehensive income to income was $(250)\nmillion, $43 million and $149 million for 2011, 2010 and 2009,\nrespectively.\nEmployee Benefit\nPlans\n2003 Employee Stock\nPlan\n\nThe 2003\nEmployee Stock Plan (the “2003 Plan”) is a shareholder\napproved plan that provides for broad-based equity grants to\nemployees, including executive officers. The 2003 Plan permits the\ngranting of incentive stock options, nonstatutory stock options,\nRSUs, stock appreciation rights, stock purchase rights and\nperformance-based awards. Options granted under the 2003 Plan\ngenerally expire seven to ten years after the grant date and\ngenerally become exercisable over a period of four years, based on\ncontinued employment, with either annual, semi-annual or quarterly\nvesting. In general, RSUs granted under the 2003 Plan vest over two\nto four years, based on continued employment and are settled upon\nvesting in shares of the Company’s common stock on a\none-for-one basis. Each share issued with respect to an award\ngranted under the 2003 Plan (other than a stock option or stock\nappreciation right) reduces the number of shares available for\ngrant under the plan by two shares, whereas shares issued in\nrespect of an option or stock appreciation right count against the\nnumber of shares available for grant on a one-for-one basis. As of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, approximately 50.8\xa0million shares\nwere reserved for future issuance under the 2003 Plan.\n\n\xa0\n1997 Director Stock\nPlan\n\nThe 1997\nDirector Stock Plan (the “Director Plan”) is a\nshareholder approved plan that (i)\xa0permits the Company to\ngrant awards of RSUs or stock options to the Company’s\nnon-employee directors, (ii)\xa0provides for automatic initial\ngrants of RSUs upon a non-employee director joining the Board and\nautomatic annual grants of RSUs at each annual meeting of\nshareholders, and (iii)\xa0permits the Board to prospectively\nchange the relative mixture of stock options and RSUs for the\ninitial and annual award grants and the methodology for determining\nthe number of shares of the Company’s common stock subject to\nthese grants without shareholder approval. Each share issued with\nrespect to RSUs granted under the Director Plan reduces the number\nof shares available for grant under the plan by two shares. The\nDirector Plan expires November\xa09, 2019. As of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, approximately 190,000 shares were reserved\nfor future issuance under the Director Plan.\nRule 10b5-1 Trading\nPlans\n\nDuring the\nfourth quarter of 2011, executive officers Timothy D. Cook, Peter\nOppenheimer, D. Bruce Sewell, Phil Schiller and Jeffrey E.\nWilliams, and directors William V. Campbell and Arthur D. Levinson\nhad trading plans pursuant to Rule 10b5-1(c)(1) of the Securities\nExchange Act of 1934, as amended (the “Exchange Act”).\nA trading plan is a written document that pre-establishes the\namounts, prices and dates (or a formula for determining the\namounts, prices and dates) of future purchases or sales of the\nCompany’s stock, including the exercise and sale of employee\nstock options and shares acquired pursuant to the Company’s\nemployee stock purchase plan and upon vesting of RSUs.\nEmployee Stock Purchase\nPlan\n\nThe Employee\nStock Purchase Plan (the “Purchase Plan”) is a\nshareholder approved plan under which substantially all employees\nmay purchase the Company’s common stock through payroll\ndeductions at a price equal to 85% of the lower of the fair market\nvalues of the stock as of the beginning or the end of six-month\noffering periods. An employee’s payroll deductions under the\nPurchase Plan are limited to 10% of the employee’s\ncompensation and employees may not purchase more than $25,000 of\nstock during any calendar year. As of September\xa024, 2011,\napproximately 3.1\xa0million shares were reserved for future\nissuance under the Purchase Plan.\nEmployee Savings\nPlan\n\nThe Employee\nSavings Plan (the “Savings Plan”) is a deferred salary\narrangement under Section\xa0401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code.\nUnder the Savings Plan, participating U.S. employees may defer a\nportion of their pre-tax earnings, up to the IRS annual\ncontribution limit ($16,500 for calendar year 2011). The Company\nmatches 50% to 100% of each employee’s contributions,\ndepending on length of service, up to a maximum 6% of the\nemployee’s eligible earnings. The Company’s matching\ncontributions to the Savings Plan were $90 million, $72 million and\n$59 million in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.\n\n\xa0\nRestricted Stock\nUnits\n\nA summary of\nthe 2011\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n14,446\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n231.49\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n5,840,503\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nThe fair value\nas of the vesting date of RSUs was $1.5 billion, $1.0 billion and\n$221 million for 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively. The majority of\nRSUs that vested in 2011, 2010 and 2009, were net-share settled\nsuch that the Company withheld shares with value equivalent to the\nemployees’ minimum statutory obligation for the applicable\nincome and other employment taxes, and remitted the cash to the\nappropriate taxing authorities. The total shares withheld were\napproximately 1.6\xa0million, 1.8\xa0million and 707,000 for\n2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively, and were based on the value of\nthe RSUs on their vesting date as determined by the Company’s\nclosing stock price. Total payments for the employees’ tax\nobligations to the taxing authorities were $520 million, $406\nmillion and $82 million in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively, and\nare reflected as a financing activity within the Consolidated\nStatements of Cash Flows.\xa0These net-share settlements had the\neffect of share repurchases by the Company as they reduced and\nretired the number of shares that would have otherwise been issued\nas a result of the vesting and did not represent an expense to the\nCompany.\n\n\xa0\nStock Option\nActivity\n\nA summary of\nthe Company’s stock option activity and at\nSeptember\xa024, 2011\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n11,866\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n108.64\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n2.38\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n3,508,243\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nExercisable at\nSeptember\xa024, 2011\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n11,089\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n104.97\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n2.31\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n3,319,374\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nExpected to vest after\nSeptember\xa024, 2011\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n777\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n161.23\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n3.38\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n188,869\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nAggregate\nintrinsic value represents the value of the Company’s closing\nstock price on the last trading day of the fiscal period in excess\nof the weighted-average exercise price multiplied by the number of\noptions outstanding or exercisable. Total intrinsic value of\noptions at time of exercise was $2.6 billion, $2.0 billion and $827\nmillion for 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.\nShare-based\nCompensation\n\nShare-based\ncompensation cost for RSUs is measured based on the closing fair\nmarket value of the Company’s common stock on the date of\ngrant. Share-based compensation cost for stock options and employee\nstock purchase plan rights (“stock purchase rights”) is\nestimated at the grant date and offering date, respectively, based\non the fair-value as calculated by the BSM option-pricing model.\nThe BSM option-pricing model incorporates various assumptions\nincluding expected volatility, expected life and interest\nrates.\xa0The expected volatility is based on the historical\nvolatility of the Company’s common stock over the most recent\nperiod commensurate with the expected life of the Company’s\nstock options and other relevant factors including implied\nvolatility in market traded options on the Company’s common\nstock. The Company bases its expected life assumption on its\nhistorical experience and on the terms and conditions of the stock\nawards it grants to employees. The Company recognizes share-based\ncompensation cost as expense on a straight-line basis over the\nrequisite service period.\n\nThe Company\ngranted 1,370 stock options, 34,000 stock options and 234,000 stock\noptions during 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively. The\nweighted-average grant date fair value of stock options granted\nduring 2011, 2010 and 2009 was $181.13, $108.58 and $46.71 per\nshare, respectively.\n\n\xa0\n\nThe Company did\nnot assume any stock options in conjunction with business\ncombinations during 2011 or 2009. During 2010, the Company assumed\n98,000 stock options, which had a weighted-average fair value of\n$216.82 per share.\n\nThe\nweighted-average fair value of stock purchase rights per share was\n$71.47, $45.03 and $30.62 during 2011, 2010 and 2009,\nrespectively.\n\nThe following\ntable provides a summary of the share-based compensation expense\nincluded in the Consolidated Statements of Operations for the three\nyears ended September\xa024, 2011 (in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2009\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nCost of sales\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0200\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0151\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0114\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nResearch and\ndevelopment\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n450\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n323\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n258\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nSelling, general and\nadministrative\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n518\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n405\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n338\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nTotal share-based\ncompensation expense\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n1,168\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n879\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n710\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nThe income tax\nbenefit related to share-based compensation expense was $467\nmillion, $314 million and $266 million for 2011, 2010 and 2009,\nrespectively. paper\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n2,853\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2,853\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n2,237\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n616\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCorporate\nsecurities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n35,241\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n132\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(114\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n35,259\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n10\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n7,241\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n28,008\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nMunicipal\nsecurities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n3,411\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n56\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n3,467\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n595\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n2,872\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nSubtotal\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n75,423\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n264\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(124)\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n75,563\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n5,001\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n14,944\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n55,618\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTotal\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n81,464\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n264\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(158\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n81,570\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n9,815\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n16,137\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n55,618\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\ of deposit and\ntime deposits\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n2,735\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n5\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(1\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2,739\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n374\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n850\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1,515\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCommercial paper\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n3,168\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n3,168\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1,889\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1,279\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCorporate\nsecurities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n17,349\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n102\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(9\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n17,442\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n58\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n4,522\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n12,862\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nMunicipal\nsecurities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1,899\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n19\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(1\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n1,917\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n374\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1,543\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nSubtotal\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n46,388\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n191\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(11\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n46,568\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n6,818\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n14,359\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n25,391\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTotal\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n50,831\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n191\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(11\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n51,011\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n11,261\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n14,359\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n25,391\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\nThe net\nunrealized gains as of September\xa024, 2011 and\nSeptember\xa025, 2010 related primarily to long-term marketable\nsecurities. The Company may sell certain of its marketable\nsecurities prior to their stated maturities for strategic reasons\nincluding, but not limited to, anticipation of credit deterioration\nand duration management. The Company recognized net realized gains\nof $110 million during 2011 and no significant net realized gains\nor losses during 2010 and 2009 related to such sales. The\nmaturities of the Company’s long-term marketable securities\ngenerally range from one year to five years.\n\nAs of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011 and September\xa025, 2010, gross\nunrealized losses related to individual securities that had been in\na continuous loss position for 12 months or longer were not\nsignificant.\n\nThe Company\nconsiders the declines in market value of its marketable securities\ninvestment portfolio to be temporary in nature. The Company\ntypically invests in highly-rated securities, and its policy\ngenerally limits the amount of credit exposure to any one issuer.\nThe Company’s investment policy requires investments to\ngenerally be investment grade, with the primary objective of\nminimizing the potential risk of principal loss. Fair values were\ndetermined for each individual security in the investment\nportfolio. When evaluating the investments for other-than-temporary\nimpairment, the Company reviews factors such as the length of time\nand extent to which fair value has been below cost basis, the\nfinancial condition of the issuer and any changes thereto, and the\nCompany’s intent to sell, or whether it is more likely than\nnot it will be required to sell, the investment before recovery of\nthe investment’s amortized cost basis. During 2011, 2010 and\n2009, the Company did not recognize any significant impairment\ncharges. As of September\xa024, 2011, the Company does not\nconsider any of its investments to be other-than-temporarily\nimpaired.\nDerivative Financial\nInstruments\n\nThe Company\nuses derivatives to partially offset its business exposure to\nforeign currency exchange risk. The Company may enter into foreign\ncurrency forward and option contracts to offset some of the foreign\nexchange risk on expected future cash flows on certain forecasted\nrevenue and cost of sales, on net investments in certain foreign\nsubsidiaries, and on certain existing assets and\nliabilities.\n\nTo help protect\ngross margins from fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates,\ncertain of the Company’s subsidiaries whose functional\ncurrency is the U.S. dollar hedge a portion of forecasted foreign\ncurrency revenue. The Company’s subsidiaries whose functional\ncurrency is not the U.S. dollar and who sell in local currencies\nmay hedge a portion of forecasted inventory purchases not\ndenominated in the subsidiaries’ functional currencies. The\nCompany typically hedges portions of its forecasted foreign\ncurrency exposure associated with revenue and inventory purchases\ngenerally up to six months.\n\nTo help protect\nthe net investment in a foreign operation from adverse changes in\nforeign currency exchange rates, the Company may enter into foreign\ncurrency forward and option contracts to offset the changes in the\ncarrying amounts of these investments due to fluctuations in\nforeign currency exchange rates.\n\nThe Company may\nalso enter into foreign currency forward and option contracts to\npartially offset the foreign currency exchange gains and losses\ngenerated by the re-measurement of certain assets and liabilities\ndenominated in non-functional currencies. However, the Company may\nchoose not to hedge certain foreign currency exchange exposures for\na variety of reasons including, but not limited to, accounting\nconsiderations and the prohibitive economic cost of hedging\nparticular exposures. There can be no assurance the hedges will\noffset more than a portion of the financial impact resulting from\nmovements in foreign currency exchange rates.\n\nThe Company\nrecords all derivatives on the Consolidated Balance Sheets at fair\nvalue. The Company’s accounting policies for these\ninstruments are based on whether the instruments are designated as\nhedge or non-hedge instruments. The effective portions of cash flow\nhedges are recorded in AOCI until the hedged item is recognized in\nearnings. The effective portions of net investment hedges are\nrecorded in other comprehensive income as a part of the cumulative\ntranslation adjustment. The ineffective portions of cash flow\nhedges and net investment hedges are recorded in other income and\nexpense. Derivatives that are not designated as hedging instruments\nare adjusted to fair value through earnings in the financial\nstatement line item the derivative relates to.\n\nThe Company had\na net deferred gain associated with cash flow hedges of\napproximately $290 million and a net deferred loss associated with\ncash flow hedges of approximately $252 million, net of taxes,\nrecorded in AOCI as of September\xa024, 2011 and\nSeptember\xa025, 2010, respectively. Deferred gains and losses\nassociated with cash flow hedges of foreign currency revenue are\nrecognized as a component of net sales in the same period as the\nrelated revenue is recognized, and deferred gains and losses\nrelated to cash flow hedges of inventory purchases are recognized\nas a component of cost of sales in the same period as the related\ncosts are recognized. Substantially all of the Company’s\nhedged transactions as of September\xa024, 2011 are expected to\noccur within six months.\n\nDerivative\ninstruments designated as cash flow hedges must be de-designated as\nhedges when it is probable the forecasted hedged transaction will\nnot occur in the initially identified time period or within a\nsubsequent two-month time period. Deferred gains and losses in AOCI\nassociated with such derivative instruments are reclassified\nimmediately into other income and expense. Any subsequent changes\nin fair value of such derivative instruments are reflected in other\nincome and expense unless they are re-designated as hedges of other\ntransactions. The Company did not recognize any significant net\ngains or losses related to the loss of hedge designation on\ndiscontinued cash flow hedges during 2011, 2010 and\n2009.\n\nThe\nCompany’s unrealized net gains and losses on net investment\nhedges, included in the cumulative translation adjustment account\nof AOCI, were not significant as of September\xa024, 2011 and\nSeptember\xa025, 2010, respectively. The ineffective portions and\namounts excluded from the effectiveness test of net investment\nhedges are recorded in other income and expense.\n\nThe Company\nrecognized in other income and expense a net loss of $158 million,\n$123 million and $133 million on foreign currency forward and\noption contracts not designated as hedging instruments during 2011,\n2010 and 2009, respectively. These amounts represent the net gain\nor loss on the derivative contracts and do not include changes in\nthe related exposures, which generally offset a portion of the gain\nor loss on the derivative contracts.\n\nThe following\ntable summarizes the notional principal amounts of the\nCompany’s outstanding derivative instruments and credit risk\namounts associated with outstanding or unsettled derivative\ninstruments as of September\xa024, 2011 and September\xa025,\n2010 (in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nNotional\nPrincipal\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nCredit\xa0Risk\nAmounts\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nNotional\nPrincipal\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nCredit\xa0Risk\nAmounts\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nInstruments qualifying as\naccounting hedges:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nForeign exchange\ncontracts\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n13,705\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n537\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n13,957\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n62\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nInstruments other than\naccounting hedges:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nForeign exchange\ncontracts\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n9,891\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n56\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n10,727\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n45\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nThe notional\nprincipal amounts for outstanding derivative instruments provide\none measure of the transaction volume outstanding and do not\nrepresent the amount of the Company’s exposure to credit or\nmarket loss. The credit risk amounts represent the Company’s\ngross exposure to potential accounting loss on derivative\ninstruments that are outstanding or unsettled if all counterparties\nfailed to perform according to the terms of the contract, based on\nthen-current currency exchange rates at each respective date. The\nCompany’s gross exposure on these transactions may be further\nmitigated by collateral received from certain counterparties. The\nCompany’s exposure to credit loss and market risk will vary\nover time as a function of currency exchange rates. Although the\ntable above reflects the notional principal and credit risk amounts\nof the Company’s foreign exchange instruments, it does not\nreflect the gains or losses associated with the exposures and\ntransactions that the foreign exchange instruments are intended to\nhedge. The amounts ultimately realized upon settlement of these\nfinancial instruments, together with the gains and losses on the\nunderlying exposures, will depend on actual market conditions\nduring the remaining life of the instruments.\n\nThe Company\ngenerally enters into master netting arrangements, which reduce\ncredit risk by permitting net settlement of transactions with the\nsame counterparty. To further limit credit risk, the Company\ngenerally enters into collateral security arrangements that provide\nfor collateral to be received or posted when the net fair value of\ncertain financial instruments fluctuates from contractually\nestablished thresholds. The Company presents its derivative assets\nand derivative liabilities at their gross fair values. As of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, the Company received cash collateral\nrelated to the derivative instruments under its collateral security\narrangements of $288 million, which it recorded as accrued expenses\nin the Consolidated Balance Sheet.\xa0As of September\xa025,\n2010, the Company posted cash collateral related to the derivative\ninstruments under its collateral security arrangements of $445\nmillion, which it recorded as other current assets in the\nConsolidated Balance Sheet. The Company did not have any derivative\ninstruments with credit-risk related contingent features that would\nrequire it to post additional collateral as of September\xa024,\n2011 or September\xa025, 2010.\n\nThe following\ntables summarize the gross fair value of the Company’s\nderivative instruments as reflected in the Consolidated Balance\nSheets as of September\xa024, 2011 and September\xa025, 2010\n(in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nSeptember\xa024,\n2011\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nFair\xa0Value\xa0of\nDerivatives\nDesignated\xa0as\nHedge\xa0Instruments\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nFair\xa0Value\xa0of\nDerivatives\xa0Not\nDesignated exchange\ncontracts\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n62\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n45\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n107\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDerivative exchange\ncontracts\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n488\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n118\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n606\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n(a)\n\nThe fair value of derivative assets is measured using Level 2\nfair value inputs and is recorded as other current assets in the\nConsolidated Balance Sheets.\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n(b)\n\nThe fair value of derivative liabilities is measured using\nLevel 2 fair value inputs and is recorded as accrued expenses in\nthe Consolidated Balance Sheets.\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\nThe following\ntable summarizes the pre-tax effect of the Company’s\nderivative instruments designated as cash flow and net investment\nhedges in the consolidated financial statements for the years ended\nSeptember\xa024, 2011 and September\xa025, 2010 and\nexpense\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n1\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nTotal\n\n\xa0\n$\n110\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(308\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(704\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n115\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(212\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(174\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n(a)\n\nIncludes gains/(losses) reclassified from AOCI into income for\nthe effective portion of cash flow hedges, of which $(349) million\nand $(355) million were recognized within net sales and cost of\nsales, respectively, within the Consolidated Statement of\nOperations for the year ended September\xa024, 2011. There were\nno amounts reclassified from AOCI into income for the effective\nportion of net investment hedges for the year ended\nSeptember\xa024, 2011.\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n(b)\n\nIncludes gains/(losses) reclassified from AOCI into income for\nthe effective portion of cash flow hedges, of which $158 million\nand $(43) million were recognized within net sales and cost of\nsales, respectively, within the Consolidated Statement of\nOperations for the year ended September\xa025, 2010. There were\nno amounts reclassified from AOCI into income for the effective\nportion of net investment hedges for the year ended\nSeptember\xa025, 2010.\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n(c)\n\nRefer to Note 6, “Shareholders’ Equity and\nShare-based Compensation” of this Form 10-K, which summarizes\nthe activity in AOCI related to derivatives.\n\n\n\nAccounts\nReceivable\nTrade\nReceivables\n\nThe Company has\nconsiderable trade receivables outstanding with its third-party\ncellular network carriers, wholesalers, retailers, value-added\nresellers, small and mid-sized businesses, and education,\nenterprise and government customers. The Company generally does not\nrequire collateral from its customers; however, the Company will\nrequire collateral in certain instances to limit credit risk. In\naddition, when possible, the Company attempts to limit credit risk\non trade receivables with credit insurance for certain customers or\nby requiring third-party financing, loans or leases to support\ncredit exposure. These credit-financing arrangements are directly\nbetween the third-party financing company and the end customer. As\nsuch, the Company generally does not assume any recourse or credit\nrisk sharing related to any of these arrangements.\n\nAs of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, there were no customers that accounted for\n10% or more of the Company’s total trade receivables. Trade\nreceivables from two of the Company’s customers accounted for\n15% and 12% of total trade receivables as of September\xa025,\n2010. The Company’s cellular network carriers accounted for\n52% and 64% of trade receivables as of September\xa024, 2011 and\nSeptember\xa025, 2010, respectively. The additions and write-offs\nto the Company’s allowance for doubtful accounts during 2011,\n2010 and 2009 were not significant.\n\n\xa0\nVendor Non-Trade\nReceivables\n\nThe Company has\nnon-trade receivables from certain of its manufacturing vendors\nresulting from the sale of components to these manufacturing\nvendors who manufacture sub-assemblies or assemble final products\nfor the Company. The Company purchases these components directly\nfrom suppliers. Vendor non-trade receivables from two of the\nCompany’s vendors accounted for 53% and 29% of total\nnon-trade receivables as of September\xa024, 2011 and vendor\nnon-trade receivables from two of the Company’s vendors\naccounted for 57% and 24% of total non-trade receivables as of\nSeptember\xa025, 2010. The Company does not reflect the sale of\nthese components in net sales and does not recognize any profits on\nthese sales until the related products are sold by the Company, at\nwhich time any profit is recognized as a reduction of cost of\nsales.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'September\xa024,\n2011', ['Segment Information and Geographic Data', '12 Months Ended']
['Sep. 24, 2011']
['Segment Information and Geographic Data', 'Note 8 –\nSegment Information and Geographic Data\n\nThe Company\nreports segment information based on the “management”\napproach. The management approach designates the internal reporting\nused by management for making decisions and assessing performance\nas the source of the Company’s reportable\nsegments.\n\nThe Company\nmanages its business primarily on a geographic basis. Accordingly,\nthe Company determined its reportable operating segments, which are\ngenerally based on the nature and location of its customers, to be\nthe Americas, Europe, Japan, Asia-Pacific and Retail operations.\nThe results of the Americas, Europe, Japan and Asia-Pacific\nreportable segments do not include results of the Retail segment.\nThe Americas segment includes both North and South America. The\nEurope segment includes European countries, as well as the Middle\nEast and Africa. The Asia-Pacific segment includes Australia and\nAsian countries, other than Japan. The Retail segment operates\nApple retail stores in 11 countries. Each reportable operating\nsegment provides similar hardware and software products and similar\nservices. The accounting policies of the various segments are the\nsame as those described in Note 1, “Summary of Significant\nAccounting Policies.”\n\nThe Company\nevaluates the performance of its operating segments based on net\nsales and operating income. Net sales for geographic segments are\ngenerally based on the location of customers, while Retail segment\nnet sales are based on sales from the Company’s retail\nstores. Operating income for each segment includes net sales to\nthird parties, related cost of sales and operating expenses\ndirectly attributable to the segment. Advertising expenses are\ngenerally included in the geographic segment in which the\nexpenditures are incurred. Operating income for each segment\nexcludes other income and expense and certain expenses managed\noutside the operating segments. Costs excluded from segment\noperating income include various corporate expenses, such as\nmanufacturing costs and variances not included in standard costs,\nresearch and development, corporate marketing expenses, share-based\ncompensation expense, income taxes, various nonrecurring charges,\nand other separately managed general and administrative costs. The\nCompany does not include intercompany transfers between segments\nfor management reporting purposes. Segment assets exclude corporate\nassets, such as cash and cash equivalents, short-term and long-term\nmarketable securities, other long-term investments, manufacturing\nand corporate facilities, product tooling and manufacturing process\nequipment, miscellaneous corporate infrastructure, goodwill and\nother acquired intangible assets. Except for the Retail segment,\ncapital asset purchases for long-lived assets are not reported to\nmanagement by segment. Cash payments for capital asset purchases by\nthe Retail segment were $612 million, $392 million and $369 million\nfor 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.\n\nThe Company has\ncertain retail stores that have been designed and built to serve as\nhigh-profile venues to promote brand awareness and serve as\nvehicles for corporate sales and marketing activities. Because of\ntheir unique design elements, locations and size, these stores\nrequire substantially more investment than the Company’s more\ntypical retail stores. The Company allocates certain operating\nexpenses associated with its high-profile stores to corporate\nexpense to reflect the estimated Company-wide benefit. The\nallocation of these operating costs to corporate expense is based\non the amount incurred for a high-profile store in excess of that\nincurred by a more typical Company retail location. The Company had\nopened a total of 19 high-profile stores as of September\xa024,\n2011. Amounts allocated to corporate expense resulting from the\noperations of high-profile stores were $102 million, $75 million\nand $65 million for 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.\n\n\xa0\n\nSummary\ninformation by operating segment for the three years ended\nSeptember\xa024, 2011 is as follows (in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2009\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nAmericas:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNet sales\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n38,315\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n24,498\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n18,981\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nOperating income\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n13,538\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n7,590\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n6,658\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDepreciation, amortization\nand ["- DefinitionThe entire disclosure for reporting segments including data and tables. Reportable segments include those that meet any of the following quantitative thresholds a) it's reported revenue, including sales to external customers and intersegment sales or transfers is 10 percent or more of the combined revenue, internal and external, of all operating segments b) the absolute amount of its reported profit or loss is 10 percent or more of the greater, in absolute amount of 1) the combined reported profit of all operating segments that did not report a loss or 2) the combined reported loss of all operating segments that did report a loss c) its assets are 10 percent or more of the combined assets of all operating segments.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 280 ['- DefinitionThe entire disclosure for the quarterly financial data in the annual financial statements.  The disclosure may include a tabular presentation of financial information for each fiscal quarter for the current and previous year, including revenues, gross profit, income or loss before extraordinary items and earnings per share data. It also includes an indication if the information in the note is unaudited, comments on the aggregate effect of year-end adjustments, and an explanation of matters or transactions that affect comparability or are pertinent to an understanding of the information furnished.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher SEC -Name Staff Accounting Bulletin (SAB) -Number Topic 6 -Section G -Subsection 1Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 270 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 12 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6372559&loc=d3e725-108305Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher AICPA -Name Accounting Principles Board Opinion (APB) -Number 28 -Paragraph 23, 24 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009.
