['Commitments and Contingencies', '12 Months Ended']
['Sep. 24, 2011']
['Commitments and Contingencies', 'Note 7 –\nCommitments and Contingencies\nAccrued Warranty and\nIndemnification\n\nThe Company\noffers a basic limited parts and labor warranty on its hardware\nproducts. The basic warranty period for hardware products is\ntypically one year from the date of purchase by the end-user. The\nCompany also offers a 90-day basic warranty for its service parts\nused to repair the Company’s hardware products. The Company\nprovides currently for the estimated cost that may be incurred\nunder its basic limited product warranties at the time related\nrevenue is recognized. Factors considered in determining\nappropriate accruals for product warranty obligations include the\nsize of the installed base of products subject to warranty\nprotection, historical and projected warranty claim rates,\nhistorical and projected cost-per-claim, and knowledge of specific\nproduct failures that are outside of the Company’s typical\nexperience. The Company assesses the adequacy of its pre-existing\nwarranty liabilities and adjusts the amounts as necessary based on\nactual experience and changes in future estimates.\n\nThe following\ntable reconciles changes in the Company’s accrued warranty\nand related costs for the three years ended September\xa024, 2011\n(in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2009\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nBeginning accrued warranty\nand related costs\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0761\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0577\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0671\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCost of warranty\nclaims\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(1,147\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(713\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(534\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nAccruals for product\nwarranty\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1,626\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n897\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n440\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nEnding accrued warranty and\nrelated costs\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n1,240\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n761\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n577\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nThe Company\ngenerally does not indemnify end-users of its operating system and\napplication software against legal claims that the software\ninfringes third-party intellectual property rights. Other\nagreements entered into by the Company sometimes include\nindemnification provisions under which the Company could be subject\nto costs and/or damages in the event of an infringement claim\nagainst the Company or an indemnified third-party. However, the\nCompany has not been required to make any significant payments\nresulting from such an infringement claim asserted against it or an\nindemnified third-party. In the opinion of management, there was\nnot at least a reasonable possibility the Company may have incurred\na material loss with respect to indemnification of end-users of its\noperating system or application software for infringement of\nthird-party intellectual property rights. The Company did not\nrecord a liability for infringement costs related to\nindemnification as of either September\xa024, 2011 or\nSeptember\xa025, 2010.\n\nThe Company has\nentered into indemnification agreements with its directors and\nexecutive officers. Under these agreements, the Company has agreed\nto indemnify such individuals to the fullest extent permitted by\nlaw against liabilities that arise by reason of their status as\ndirectors or officers and to advance expenses incurred by such\nindividuals in connection with related legal proceedings. It is not\npossible to determine the maximum potential amount of payments the\nCompany could be required to make under these agreements due to the\nlimited history of prior indemnification claims and the unique\nfacts and circumstances involved in each claim. However, the\nCompany maintains directors and officers liability insurance\ncoverage to reduce its exposure to such obligations, and payments\nmade under these agreements historically have not been\nmaterial.\nConcentrations in the\nAvailable Sources of Supply of Materials and Product\n\nAlthough most\ncomponents essential to the Company’s business are generally\navailable from multiple sources, a number of components are\ncurrently obtained from single or limited sources, which subjects\nthe Company to significant supply and pricing risks. Many\ncomponents that are available from multiple sources are at times\nsubject to industry-wide shortages and significant commodity\npricing fluctuations. In addition, the Company has entered into\nvarious agreements for the supply of components; however there can\nbe no guarantee that the Company will be able to extend or renew\nthese agreements on similar terms, or at all. Therefore, the\nCompany remains subject to significant risks of supply shortages\nand price increases that can materially adversely affect its\nfinancial condition and operating results.\n\nThe Company and\nother participants in the mobile communication and media device,\nand personal computer industries also compete for various\ncomponents with other industries that have experienced increased\ndemand for their products. The Company also uses some custom\ncomponents that are not common to the rest of these industries, and\nnew products introduced by the Company often utilize custom\ncomponents available from only one source. When a component or\nproduct uses new technologies, initial capacity constraints may\nexist until the suppliers’ yields have matured or\nmanufacturing capacity has increased. If the Company’s supply\nof components for a new or existing product were delayed or\nconstrained, or if an outsourcing partner delayed shipments of\ncompleted products to the Company, the Company’s financial\ncondition and operating results could be materially adversely\naffected. The Company’s business and financial performance\ncould also be materially adversely affected depending on the time\nrequired to obtain sufficient quantities from the original source,\nor to identify and obtain sufficient quantities from an alternative\nsource. Continued availability of these components at acceptable\nprices, or at all, may be affected if those suppliers concentrated\non the production of common components instead of components\ncustomized to meet the Company’s requirements.\n\nSubstantially\nall of the Company’s hardware products are manufactured by\noutsourcing partners that are primarily located in Asia. A\nsignificant concentration of this manufacturing is currently\nperformed by a small number of outsourcing partners, often in\nsingle locations. Certain of these outsourcing partners are the\nsole-sourced suppliers of components and manufacturer for many of\nthe Company’s products. Although the Company works closely\nwith its outsourcing partners on manufacturing schedules, the\nCompany’s operating results could be adversely affected if\nits outsourcing partners were unable to meet their production\ncommitments. The Company’s purchase commitments typically\ncover its requirements for periods up to 150 days.\nLong-Term Supply\nAgreements\n\nThe Company has\nentered into long-term agreements to secure the supply of certain\ninventory components. These agreements generally expire between\n2012 and 2022. As of September\xa024, 2011, the Company had a\ntotal of $2.3 billion of inventory component prepayments\noutstanding, of which $728 million are classified as other current\nassets and $1.6 billion are classified as other assets in the\nConsolidated Balance Sheets. The Company had a total of $956\nmillion of inventory component prepayments outstanding as of\nSeptember\xa025, 2010. The Company’s outstanding\nprepayments will be applied to certain inventory component\npurchases made during the term of each respective\nagreement.\nOther Off-Balance Sheet\nCommitments\nLease\nCommitments\n\nThe Company\nleases various equipment and facilities, including retail space,\nunder noncancelable operating lease arrangements. The Company does\nnot currently utilize any other off-balance sheet financing\narrangements. The major facility leases are typically for terms not\nexceeding 10 years and generally provide renewal options for terms\nnot exceeding five additional years. Leases for retail space are\nfor terms ranging from five to 20 years, the majority of which are\nfor ten years, and often contain multi-year renewal options. As of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, the Company’s total future minimum\nlease payments under noncancelable operating leases were $3.0\nbillion, of which $2.4 billion related to leases for retail\nspace.\n\nRent expense\nunder all operating leases, including both cancelable and\nnoncancelable leases, was $338 million, $271 million and $231\nmillion in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively. Future minimum lease\npayments under noncancelable operating leases having remaining\nterms in excess of one year as of September\xa024, 2011, are as\nfollows (in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYears\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n2012\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n338\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2013\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n365\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2014\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n362\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2015\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n345\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2016\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n320\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nThereafter\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1,302\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nTotal minimum lease\npayments\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n3,032\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\nOther\nCommitments\n\nAs of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, the Company had outstanding off-balance\nsheet commitments for outsourced manufacturing and component\npurchases of $13.9 billion.\n\nAdditionally,\nother outstanding obligations were $2.4 billion as of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, and were comprised mainly of commitments\nunder long-term supply agreements to make additional inventory\ncomponent prepayments and to acquire capital equipment, commitments\nto acquire product tooling and manufacturing process equipment, and\ncommitments related to advertising, research and development,\nInternet and telecommunications services and other\nobligations.\nContingencies\n\nThe Company is\nsubject to various legal proceedings and claims that have arisen in\nthe ordinary course of business and have not been fully\nadjudicated, which are discussed in Part I, Item\xa03 of this\nForm 10-K under the heading “Legal Proceedings” and in\nPart I Item\xa01A under the heading “Risk Factors.”\nIn the opinion of management, there was not at least a reasonable\npossibility the Company may have incurred a material loss, or a\nmaterial loss in excess of a recorded accrual, with respect to loss\ncontingencies. However, the outcome of litigation is inherently\nuncertain. Therefore, although management considers the likelihood\nof such an outcome to be remote, if one or more of these legal\nmatters were resolved against the Company in the same reporting\nperiod for amounts in excess of management’s expectations,\nthe Company’s consolidated financial statements of a\nparticular reporting period could be materially adversely\naffected.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '2011', '', '', '2010', '', '', '2009', '', 'Beginning accrued warranty\nand related costs', '', '$', '761', '', '', '$', '577', '', '', '$', '671', '', 'Cost of warranty\nclaims', '', '', '(1,147', ')', '', '', '(713', ')', '', '', '(534', ')', 'Accruals for product\nwarranty', '', '', '1,626', '', '', '', '897', '', '', '', '440', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Ending accrued warranty and\nrelated costs', '', '$', '1,240', '', '', '$', '761', '', '', '$', '577', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Years', '', '', '', '2012', '', '$', '338', '', '2013', '', '', '365', '', '2014', '', '', '362', '', '2015', '', '', '345', '', '2016', '', '', '320', '', 'Thereafter', '', '', '1,302', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Total minimum lease\npayments', '', '$', '3,032', '', '', '', '', '', '']

['X']
["- DefinitionIncludes currency on hand as well as demand deposits with banks or financial institutions. It also includes other kinds of accounts that have the general characteristics of demand deposits in that the Entity may deposit additional funds at any time and also effectively may withdraw funds at any time without prior notice or penalty. Cash equivalents, excluding items classified as marketable securities, include short-term, highly liquid investments that are both readily convertible to known amounts of cash, and so near their maturity that they present minimal risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates. Generally, only investments with original maturities of three months or less qualify under that definition. Original maturity means original maturity to the entity holding the investment. For example, both a three-month US Treasury bill and a three-year Treasury note purchased three months from maturity qualify as cash equivalents. However, a Treasury note purchased three years ago does not become a cash equivalent when its remaining maturity is three months. Compensating balance arrangements that do not legally restrict the withdrawal or usage of cash amounts may be reported as Cash and Cash Equivalents, while legally restricted deposits held as compensating balances against borrowing arrangements, contracts entered into with others, or company statements of intention with regard to particular deposits are not generally reported as cash and cash equivalents. Includes cash and cash equivalents associated with the entity's continuing operations. Excludes cash and cash equivalents associated with the disposal group (and discontinued operation).+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 210 -SubTopic 10 -Section S99 -Paragraph 1 -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02.1) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6877327&loc=d3e13212-122682Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher SEC -Name Regulation S-X (SX) -Number 210 -Section 02 -Paragraph 1 -Article 5Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 95 -Paragraph 7 -Footnote 1 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ["- DefinitionThe net cash from (used in) all of the entity's operating activities, including those of discontinued operations, of the reporting entity. Operating activities generally involve producing and delivering goods and providing services. Operating activity cash flows include transactions, adjustments, and changes in value that are not defined as investing or financing activities. While for technical reasons this element has no balance attribute, the default assumption is a debit balance consistent with its label.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 230 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 24 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6943989&loc=d3e3521-108585Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 230 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 25 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6943989&loc=d3e3536-108585Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 95 -Paragraph 28 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['- DefinitionThe sum of the tax effects as of the balance sheet date of the amounts of all future tax deductions arising from temporary differences between tax basis and generally accepted accounting principles basis recognition of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses, which can only be deducted for tax purposes when permitted under enacted tax laws ( before the valuation allowance, if any, to reduce such sum amount to net realizable value). ['Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets', '12 Months Ended']
['Sep. 24, 2011']
['Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets', 'Note 4 – Goodwill\nand Other Intangible Assets\n\nThe Company is\ncurrently amortizing its acquired intangible assets with definite\nlives over periods generally ranging between three to seven years.\nThe following table summarizes the components of gross and net\nintangible asset balances as of September\xa024, 2011 and\nSeptember\xa025, 2010 (in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nGross\nCarrying\nAmount\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nAccumulated\nAmortization\n\xa0\n\xa0\nNet\nCarrying\nAmount\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nGross\nCarrying\nAmount\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nAccumulated\nAmortization\n\xa0\n\xa0\nNet\nCarrying\nAmount\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nDefinite lived and\namortizable acquired intangible assets\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n3,873\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(437\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n3,436\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n487\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(245\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n242\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nIndefinite lived and\nnon-amortizable trademarks\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n100\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n100\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n100\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n100\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nTotal acquired intangible\nassets\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n3,973\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(437\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n3,536\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n587\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(245\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n342\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nDuring 2011 and\n2010, the Company completed various business acquisitions. In 2011,\nthe aggregate cash consideration, net of cash acquired, was $244\nmillion, of which $167 million was allocated to goodwill and $77\nmillion to acquired intangible assets. In 2010, the aggregate cash\nconsideration, net of cash acquired, was $638 million, of which\n$535 million was allocated to goodwill and $107 million to acquired\nintangible assets.\n\nDuring 2011,\nthe Company, as part of a consortium, acquired Nortel Networks\nCorporation’s patent portfolio for an overall purchase price\nof $4.5 billion, of which the Company’s contribution was\napproximately $2.6 billion. The majority of the acquisition price\nhas been recorded in acquired intangible assets, which the Company\nexpects to amortize over seven years. The Department of Justice is\nreviewing this transaction.\n\nThe\nCompany’s gross carrying amount of goodwill was $896 million\nand $741 million as of September\xa024, 2011 and\nSeptember\xa025, 2010, respectively. The Company did not have any\ngoodwill impairment during 2011, 2010 or 2009. The Company’s\ngoodwill is allocated primarily to the Americas and Europe\nreportable operating segments.\n\nAmortization\nexpense related to acquired intangible assets was $192 million, $69\nmillion and $53 million in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively. As of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011 the weighted-average amortization period\nfor acquired intangible assets was 6.2 years. The expected annual\namortization expense related to acquired intangible assets as of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, is as follows (in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYears\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n2012\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n520\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2013\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n596\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2014\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n608\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2015\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n441\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2016\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n426\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nThereafter\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n845\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nTotal\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n3,436', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '2011', '', '', '2010', '', '', '', 'Gross\nCarrying\nAmount', '', '', 'Accumulated\nAmortization', '', '', 'Net\nCarrying\nAmount', '', '', 'Gross\nCarrying\nAmount', '', '', 'Accumulated\nAmortization', '', '', 'Net\nCarrying\nAmount', '', 'Definite lived and\namortizable acquired intangible assets', '', '$', '3,873', '', '', '$', '(437', ')', '', '$', '3,436', '', '', '$', '487', '', '', '$', '(245', ')', '', '$', '242', '', 'Indefinite lived and\nnon-amortizable trademarks', '', '', '100', '', '', '', '0', '', '', '', '100', '', '', '', '100', '', '', '', '0', '', '', '', '100', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Total acquired intangible\nassets', '', '$', '3,973', '', '', '$', '(437', ')', '', '$', '3,536', '', '', '$', '587', '', '', '$', '(245', ')', '', '$', '342', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Years', '', '', '', '2012', '', '$', '520', '', '2013', '', '', '596', '', '2014', '', '', '608', '', '2015', '', '', '441', '', '2016', '', '', '426', '', 'Thereafter', '', '', '845', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Total', '', '$', '3,436', '', '', '', '', '', '']

['- DefinitionThe entire disclosure for the aggregate amount of goodwill and a description of intangible assets, which may include (a) for amortizable intangible assets (also referred to as finite-lived intangible assets), the carrying amount, the amount of any significant residual value, and the weighted-average amortization period, (b) for intangible assets not subject to amortization (also referred to as indefinite-lived intangible assets), the carrying amount, and (c) the amount of research and development assets acquired and written off in the period, including the line item in the income statement in which the amounts written off are aggregated, if not readily apparent from the income statement. Also discloses (a) for amortizable intangibles assets in total and by major class, the gross carrying amount and accumulated amortization, the total amortization expense for the period, and the estimated aggregate amortization expense for each of the five succeeding fiscal years, (b) for intangible assets not subject to amortization the carrying amount in total and by major class, and (c) for goodwill, in total and for each reportable segment, the changes in the carrying amount of goodwill during the period (including the aggregate amount of goodwill acquired, the aggregate amount of impairment losses recognized, and the amount of goodwill included in the gain (loss) on disposal of a reporting unit). If any part of goodwill has not been allocated to a reportable segment, discloses the unallocated amount and the reasons for not allocating. For each impairment loss recognized related to an intangible asset (excluding goodwill), discloses: (a) a description of the impaired intangible asset and the facts and circumstances leading to the impairment, (b) the amount of the impairment loss and the method for determining fair value, (c) the caption in the income statement or the statement of activities in which the impairment loss is aggregated, and (d) the segment in which the impaired intangible asset is reported. For each goodwill impairment loss recognized, discloses: (a) a description of the facts and circumstances leading to the impairment, (b) the amount of the impairment loss and the method of determining the fair value of the associated reporting unit, and (c) if a recognized impairment loss is an estimate not finalized and the reasons why the estimate is not final.  May also disclose the nature and amount of any significant adjustments made to a previous estimate of an impairment loss.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 350 -SubTopic 20 -Section 50 -Paragraph 1 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6905597&loc=d3e13816-109267Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 350 -SubTopic 30 -Section 50 -Paragraph 1 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6905858&loc=d3e16265-109275Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 142 -Paragraph 42, 43, 44, 45, 46, 47 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['- DefinitionThis item represents the cost of debt and equity securities, which are categorized neither as held-to-maturity nor trading, net of adjustments including accretion, amortization, collection of cash, previous other-than-temporary impairments recognized in earnings (less any cumulative-effect adjustments recognized, as defined), and fair value hedge accounting adjustments, if any.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name FASB Staff Position (FSP) -Number FAS115-1/124-1 -Paragraph 7 -Footnote 2 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ["- DefinitionInvestments in debt and equity securities which are categorized neither as trading securities nor held-to-maturity securities and which are intended be sold or mature within one year from the balance sheet date or the normal operating cycle, whichever is longer. Such securities are reported at fair value; unrealized gains (losses) related to Available-for-sale Securities are excluded from earnings and reported in a separate component of shareholders' equity (other comprehensive income), unless the Available-for-sale security is designated as a hedge or is determined to have had an other than temporary decline in fair value below its amortized cost basis. All or a portion of the unrealized holding gain (loss) of an Available-for-sale security that is designated as being hedged in a fair value hedge is recognized in earnings during the period of the hedge, as are other than temporary declines in fair value below the cost basis for investments in equity securities and debt securities that an entity intends to sell or it is more likely than not that it will be required to sell before the recovery of its amortized cost basis. Other than temporary declines in fair value below the cost basis for debt securities categorized as Available-for-sale that an entity does not intend to sell and for which it is not more likely than not that the entity will be required to sell before the recovery of its amortized cost basis are bifurcated into credit losses and losses related to all other factors. Other than temporary declines in fair value below cost basis related to credit losses are recognized in earnings, and losses related to all other factors are recognized in other comprehensive income.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 320 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 2 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6871852&loc=d3e26626-111562Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 133 -Paragraph 22 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['- DefinitionThis element represents the portion of the balance sheet assertion valued at fair value by the entity whether such amount is presented as a separate caption or as a parenthetical disclosure. Additionally, this element may be used in connection with the fair value disclosures required in the footnote disclosures to the financial statements. The element may be used in both the balance sheet and disclosure in the same submission. This item represents Available-for-sale Securities which consist of all investments in certain debt and equity securities neither classified as trading or held-to-maturity securities. A debt security represents a creditor relationship with an enterprise. Debt securities include, among other items, US Treasury securities, US government securities, municipal securities, corporate bonds, convertible debt, commercial paper, and all securitized debt instruments. An equity security represents an ownership interest in an enterprise or the right to acquire or dispose of an ownership interest in an enterprise at fixed or determinable prices. Equity securities include, among other things, common stock, certain preferred stock, warrant rights, call options, and put options, but do not include convertible debt. An entity may opt to provide the reader with additional narrative text to better understand the nature of investments in debt and equity securities which are categorized as Available-for-sale.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 115 -Paragraph 12 -Subparagraph b -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ["- DefinitionInvestments in debt and equity securities which are categorized neither as held-to-maturity nor trading and which are intended to be sold or mature more than one year from the balance sheet date or operating cycle, if longer. Such securities are reported at fair value; unrealized gains (losses) related to Available-for-sale Securities are excluded from earnings and reported in a separate component of shareholders' equity (other comprehensive income), unless the Available-for-sale security is designated as a hedge or is determined to have had an other than temporary decline in fair value below its amortized cost basis. All or a portion of the unrealized holding gain (loss) of an Available-for-sale security that is designated as being hedged in a fair value hedge is recognized in earnings during the period of the hedge, as are other than temporary declines in fair value below the cost basis for investments in equity securities and debt securities that an entity intends to sell or it is more likely than not that it will be required to sell before the recovery of its amortized cost basis. Other than temporary declines in fair value below the cost basis for debt securities categorized as Available-for-sale that an entity does not intend to sell and for which it is not more likely than not that the entity will be required to sell before the recovery of its amortized cost basis are bifurcated into credit losses and losses related to all other factors. Other than temporary declines in fair value below cost basis related to credit losses are recognized in earnings, and losses related to all other factors are recognized in other comprehensive income.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 320 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 2 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6871852&loc=d3e26626-111562Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name FASB Staff Position (FSP) -Number FAS115-1/124-1 -Paragraph 15C -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['X']
["- DefinitionIncludes currency on hand as well as demand deposits with banks or financial institutions. It also includes other kinds of accounts that have the general characteristics of demand deposits in that the Entity may deposit additional funds at any time and also effectively may withdraw funds at any time without prior notice or penalty. Cash equivalents, excluding items classified as marketable securities, include short-term, highly liquid investments that are both readily convertible to known amounts of cash, and so near their maturity that they present minimal risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates. Generally, only investments with original maturities of three months or less qualify under that definition. Original maturity means original maturity to the entity holding the investment. For example, both a three-month US Treasury bill and a three-year Treasury note purchased three months from maturity qualify as cash equivalents. However, a Treasury note purchased three years ago does not become a cash equivalent when its remaining maturity is three months. Compensating balance arrangements that do not legally restrict the withdrawal or usage of cash amounts may be reported as Cash and Cash Equivalents, while legally restricted deposits held as compensating balances against borrowing arrangements, contracts entered into with others, or company statements of intention with regard to particular deposits are not generally reported as cash and cash equivalents. Includes cash and cash equivalents associated with the entity's continuing operations. Excludes cash and cash equivalents associated with the disposal group (and discontinued operation).+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 210 -SubTopic 10 -Section S99 -Paragraph 1 -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02.1) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6877327&loc=d3e13212-122682Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher SEC -Name Regulation S-X (SX) -Number 210 -Section 02 -Paragraph 1 -Article 5Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 95 -Paragraph 7 -Footnote 1 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['- DefinitionTabular disclosure of available-for-sale securities which consist of all investments in certain debt and equity securities neither classified as trading or held-to-maturity securities. A debt security represents a creditor relationship with an enterprise. Debt securities include, among other items, US Treasury securities, US government securities, municipal securities, corporate bonds, convertible debt, commercial paper, and all securitized debt instruments. An equity security represents an ownership interest in an enterprise or the right to acquire or dispose of an ownership interest in an enterprise at fixed or determinable prices. Equity securities include, among other things, common stock, certain preferred stock, warrant rights, call options, and put options, but do not include convertible debt.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 942 -SubTopic 320 -Section 50 -Paragraph 2 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6957658&loc=d3e62557-112803Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name FASB Staff Position (FSP) -Number FAS115-1/124-1 -Paragraph 17 -Subparagraph a, b -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['Sep. 24, 2011']
['Income Taxes', 'Note 5 – Income\nTaxes\n\nThe provision\nfor income taxes for the three years ended September\xa024, 2011,\nconsisted of the following (in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2009\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nFederal:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCurrent\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n3,884\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n2,150\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n1,922\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDeferred\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n2,998\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n1,676\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n1,077\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n6,882\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n3,826\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2,999\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nState:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCurrent\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n762\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n655\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n524\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDeferred\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n37\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(115\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(2\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n799\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n540\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n522\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nForeign:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCurrent\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n769\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n282\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n345\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDeferred\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(167\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(121\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(35\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n602\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n161\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n310\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nProvision for income\ntaxes\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n8,283\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n4,527\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n3,831\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nThe foreign\nprovision for income taxes is based on foreign pretax earnings of\n$24.0 billion, $13.0 billion and $6.6 billion in 2011, 2010 and\n2009, respectively. The Company’s consolidated financial\nstatements provide for any related tax liability on amounts that\nmay be repatriated, aside from undistributed earnings of certain of\nthe Company’s foreign subsidiaries that are intended to be\nindefinitely reinvested in operations outside the U.S. As of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, U.S. income taxes have not been provided\non a cumulative total of $23.4 billion of such earnings. The amount\nof unrecognized deferred tax liability related to these temporary\ndifferences is estimated to be approximately $8.0\nbillion.\n\nAs of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011 and September\xa025, 2010, $54.3 billion\nand $30.8 billion, respectively, of the Company’s cash, cash\nequivalents and marketable securities were held by foreign\nsubsidiaries and are generally based in U.S. dollar-denominated\nholdings. Amounts held by foreign subsidiaries are generally\nsubject to U.S. income taxation on repatriation to the\nU.S.\n\nDeferred tax\nassets and liabilities reflect the effects of tax losses, credits,\nand the future income tax effects of temporary differences between\nthe consolidated financial statement carrying amounts of existing\nassets and liabilities and their respective tax bases and are\nmeasured using enacted tax rates that apply to taxable income in\nthe years in which those temporary differences are expected to be\nrecovered or settled.\n\n\xa0\n\nAs of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011 and September\xa025, 2010, the\nsignificant components of the Company’s deferred tax assets\nand liabilities were (in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nDeferred tax\nassets:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAccrued liabilities and\nother reserves\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa01,610\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa01,369\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nBasis of capital assets and\ninvestments\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n390\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n179\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nShare-based\ncompensation\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n355\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n308\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nOther\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n795\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n707\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nTotal deferred tax\nassets\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n3,150\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2,563\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nLess valuation\nallowance\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nDeferred tax assets, net of\nvaluation allowance\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n3,150\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2,563\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nDeferred tax\nliabilities:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nUnremitted earning of\nforeign subsidiaries\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n8,896\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n4,979\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nOther\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n272\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n150\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nTotal deferred tax\nliabilities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n9,168\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n5,129\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nNet deferred tax\nliabilities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(6,018\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(2,566\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nA\nreconciliation of the provision for income taxes, with the amount\ncomputed by applying the statutory federal income tax rate (35% in\n2011, 2010 and 2009) to income before provision for income taxes\nfor the three years ended September\xa024, 2011, is as follows\n(in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2009\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nComputed expected\ntax\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n11,973\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa06,489\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa04,223\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nState taxes, net of federal\neffect\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n552\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n351\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n339\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nIndefinitely invested\nearnings of foreign subsidiaries\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(3,898\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(2,125\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(647\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nResearch and development\ncredit, net\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(167\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(23\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(84\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nDomestic production\nactivities deduction\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(168\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(48\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(36\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nOther\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(9\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(117\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n36\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nProvision for income\ntaxes\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n8,283\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n4,527\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n3,831\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nEffective tax\nrate\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n24.2%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n24.4%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n31.8%\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nThe\nCompany’s income taxes payable have been reduced by the tax\nbenefits from employee stock plan awards. For stock options, the\nCompany receives an income tax benefit calculated as the difference\nbetween the fair market value of the stock issued at the time of\nthe exercise and the option price, tax effected.\xa0For RSUs, the\nCompany receives an income tax benefit upon the award’s\nvesting equal to the tax effect of the underlying stock’s\nfair market value. The Company had net excess tax benefits from\nequity awards of $1.1 billion, $742 million and $246 million in\n2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively, which were reflected as\nincreases to common stock.\nUncertain Tax\nPositions\n\nTax positions\nare evaluated in a two-step process. The Company first determines\nwhether it is more likely than not that a tax position will be\nsustained upon examination. If a tax position meets the\nmore-likely-than-not recognition threshold it is then measured to\ndetermine the amount of benefit to recognize in the financial\nstatements. The tax position is measured as the largest amount of\nbenefit that is greater than 50% likely of being realized upon\nultimate settlement. The Company classifies gross interest and\npenalties and unrecognized tax benefits that are not expected to\nresult in payment or receipt of cash within one year as non-current\nliabilities in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.\n\n\xa0\n\nAs of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, the total amount of gross unrecognized tax\nbenefits was $1.4 billion, of which $563 million, if recognized,\nwould affect the Company’s effective tax rate. As of\nSeptember\xa025, 2010, the total amount of gross unrecognized tax\nbenefits was $943 million, of which $404 million, if recognized,\nwould affect the Company’s effective tax rate.\n\nThe aggregate\nchanges in the balance of gross unrecognized tax benefits, which\nexcludes interest and penalties, for the three years ended\nSeptember\xa024, 2011, is as follows (in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2009\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nBeginning\nBalance\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n943\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n971\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n506\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nIncreases related to tax\npositions taken during a prior year\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n49\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n61\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n341\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDecreases related to tax\npositions taken during a prior year\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(39\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(224\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(24\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nIncreases related to tax\npositions taken during the current year\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n425\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n240\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n151\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDecreases related to\nsettlements with taxing authorities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(102\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDecreases related to\nexpiration of statute of limitations\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(3\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(3\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(3\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nEnding Balance\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa01,375\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0943\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0971\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nThe Company\nincludes interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax\nbenefits within the provision for income taxes. As of\nSeptember\xa024, 2011 and September\xa025, 2010, the total\namount of gross interest and penalties accrued was $261 million and\n$247 million, respectively, which is classified as non-current\nliabilities in the Consolidated Balance Sheets. In connection with\ntax matters, the Company recognized interest expense in 2011 and\n2009 of $14 million and $64 million, respectively, and in 2010 the\nCompany recognized an interest benefit of $43 million.\n\nThe Company is\nsubject to taxation and files income tax returns in the U.S.\nfederal jurisdiction and in many state and foreign jurisdictions.\nFor U.S. federal income tax purposes, all years prior to 2004 are\nclosed. The Internal Revenue Service (the “IRS”) has\ncompleted its field audit of the Company’s federal income tax\nreturns for the years 2004 through 2006 and proposed certain\nadjustments. The Company has contested certain of these adjustments\nthrough the IRS Appeals Office. The IRS is currently examining the\nyears 2007 through 2009. In addition, the Company is also subject\nto audits by state, local and foreign tax authorities.\xa0In\nmajor states and major foreign jurisdictions, the years subsequent\nto 1988 and 2001, respectively, generally remain open and could be\nsubject to examination by the taxing authorities.\n\nManagement\nbelieves that an adequate provision has been made for any\nadjustments that may result from tax examinations. However, the\noutcome of tax audits cannot be predicted with certainty. If any\nissues addressed in the Company’s tax audits are resolved in\na manner not consistent with management’s expectations, the\nCompany could be required to adjust its provision for income tax in\nthe period such resolution occurs. Although timing of the\nresolution and/or closure of audits is not certain, the Company\ndoes not believe it is reasonably possible that its unrecognized\ntax benefits would materially change in the next\n12\xa0months.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '2011', '', '', '2010', '', '', '2009', '', 'Federal:', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Current', '', ["- DefinitionThe entire disclosure for income taxes. Disclosures may include net deferred tax liability or asset recognized in an enterprise's statement of financial position, net change during the year in the total valuation allowance, approximate tax effect of each type of temporary difference and carryforward that gives rise to a significant portion of deferred tax liabilities and deferred tax assets, utilization of a tax carryback, and tax uncertainties information.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 740 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 2 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6907707&loc=d3e32537-109319Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 109 -Paragraph 136, 172 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['- DefinitionTabular disclosure of unrecognized tax benefits for which a material change is reasonably possible in the next twelve months, typically including the nature of the uncertainty, the event(s) that could cause a material change, and an estimate of the range of the reasonably possible change or a statement that an estimate of the range cannot be made. An unrecognized tax benefit is the difference between a tax position taken in a tax return and the amounts recognized in the financial statements for which it is more likely than not, based on the technical merits of the position, that the tax position will not be sustained upon examination.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name FASB Interpretation (FIN) -Number 48 -Paragraph 21 -Subparagraph d -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ["- DefinitionNet of tax effect change in accumulated gains and losses from derivative instruments designated and qualifying as the effective portion of cash flow hedges after taxes. A cash flow hedge is a hedge of the exposure to variability in the cash flows of a recognized asset or liability or a forecasted transaction that is attributable to a particular risk. The change includes an entity's share of an equity investee's increase or decrease in deferred hedging gains or losses. While for technical reasons this element has no balance attribute, the default assumption is a credit balance consistent with its label.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 133 -Paragraph 31, 46 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ["- DefinitionTotal of all stockholders' equity (deficit) items, net of receivables from officers, directors, owners, and affiliates of the entity which are attributable to the parent. The amount of the economic entity's stockholders' equity attributable to the parent excludes the amount of stockholders' equity which is allocable to that ownership interest in subsidiary equity which is not attributable to the parent (noncontrolling interest, minority interest). ['(e)', 'Includes revenue recognized from iPad sales, services and\nApple-branded and third-party iPad accessories.']

Table:
['(f)', 'Includes sales of displays, wireless connectivity and\nnetworking solutions, and other hardware accessories.']

Table:
['(g)', 'Includes sales from the Mac App Store in addition to sales of\nother Apple-branded and third-party Mac\xa0software and Mac and\nInternet services.']

['- DefinitionTabular disclosure of the profit or loss and total assets for each reportable segment. An entity discloses certain information on each reportable segment if the amounts (a) are included in the measure of segment profit or loss reviewed by the chief operating decision maker or (b) are otherwise regularly provided to the chief operating decision maker, even if not included in that measure of segment profit or loss.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 280 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 21 -Subparagraph (b) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6534315&loc=d3e8721-108599Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 280 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 22 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6534315&loc=d3e8736-108599Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 131 -Paragraph 27, 28 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009.
