['Summary of Significant Accounting Policies', '12 Months Ended']
['Sep. 24, 2011']
['Summary of Significant Accounting Policies', 'Note 1\n– Summary of Significant Accounting\nPolicies\n\nApple Inc. and\nits wholly-owned subsidiaries (collectively “Apple” or\nthe “Company”) designs, manufactures, and markets\nmobile communication and media devices, personal computers, and\nportable digital music players, and sells a variety of related\nsoftware, services, peripherals, networking solutions, and\nthird-party digital content and applications. The Company sells its\nproducts worldwide through its retail stores, online stores, and\ndirect sales force, as well as through third-party cellular network\ncarriers, wholesalers, retailers and value-added resellers. In\naddition, the Company sells a variety of third-party iPhone, iPad,\nMac, and iPod compatible products including application software,\nprinters, storage devices, speakers, headphones, and various other\naccessories and supplies through its online and retail stores. The\nCompany sells to consumers, small and mid-sized businesses,\neducation, enterprise and government customers.\nBasis of Presentation\nand Preparation\n\nThe\naccompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts\nof the Company. Intercompany accounts and transactions have been\neliminated. The preparation of these consolidated financial\nstatements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting\nprinciples (“GAAP”) requires management to make\nestimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in these\nconsolidated financial statements and accompanying notes. Actual\nresults could differ materially from those estimates. Certain prior\nyear amounts in the consolidated financial statements and notes\nthereto have been reclassified to conform to the current\nyear’s presentation.\n\nThe\nCompany’s fiscal year is the 52 or 53-week period that ends\non the last Saturday of September. The Company’s fiscal years\n2011, 2010 and 2009 ended on September\xa024,\n2011,\xa0September\xa025, 2010 and September\xa026, 2009,\nrespectively, and included 52 weeks each. An additional week is\nincluded in the first fiscal quarter approximately every six years\nto realign fiscal quarters with calendar quarters. Fiscal year 2012\nwill end on September\xa029, 2012, and will span 53 weeks, with a\n14th week added to the first quarter of 2012. Unless otherwise\nstated, references to particular years or quarters refer to the\nCompany’s fiscal years ended in September and the associated\nquarters of those fiscal years.\n\nDuring the\nfirst quarter of 2011, the Company adopted the Financial Accounting\nStandard Board’s (“FASB”) new accounting\nstandard\xa0on consolidation of variable interest\nentities.\xa0This new accounting standard eliminates the\nmandatory quantitative approach in determining control\nfor\xa0evaluating whether variable interest entities need to be\nconsolidated\xa0in favor of a qualitative analysis, and requires\nan ongoing reassessment\xa0of control over such entities. The\nadoption of this new accounting standard did not impact the\nCompany’s consolidated financial statements.\nRevenue\nRecognition\n\nNet sales\nconsist primarily of revenue from the sale of hardware, software,\ndigital content and applications, peripherals, and service and\nsupport contracts. The Company recognizes revenue when persuasive\nevidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred, the sales\nprice is fixed or determinable, and collection is probable. Product\nis considered delivered to the customer once it has been shipped\nand title and risk of loss have been transferred. For most of the\nCompany’s product sales, these criteria are met at the time\nthe product is shipped. For online sales to individuals, for some\nsales to education customers in the U.S., and for certain other\nsales, the Company defers revenue until the customer receives the\nproduct because the Company legally retains a portion of the risk\nof loss on these sales during transit. The Company recognizes\nrevenue from the sale of hardware products, software bundled with\nhardware that is essential to the functionality of the hardware,\nand third-party digital content sold on the iTunes Store in\naccordance with general revenue recognition accounting guidance.\nThe Company recognizes revenue in accordance with industry specific\nsoftware accounting guidance for the following types of sales\ntransactions: (i)\xa0standalone sales of software products,\n(ii)\xa0sales of software upgrades and (iii)\xa0sales of\nsoftware bundled with hardware not essential to the functionality\nof the hardware.\n\n\xa0\n\nThe Company\nsells software and peripheral products obtained from other\ncompanies. The Company generally establishes its own pricing and\nretains related inventory risk, is the primary obligor in sales\ntransactions with its customers, and assumes the credit risk for\namounts billed to its customers. Accordingly, the Company generally\nrecognizes revenue for the sale of products obtained from other\ncompanies based on the gross amount billed. For sales of\nthird-party software applications for iPhone, iPad and iPod touch\n(“iOS devices”) and Macs made through the App Store and\nthe Mac App Store, the Company is not the primary obligor to users\nof the software, and third- party developers determine the selling\nprice of their software. Therefore, the Company accounts for such\nsales on a net basis by recognizing only the commission it retains\nfrom each sale and including that commission in net sales in the\nConsolidated Statements of Operations. The portion of the sales\nprice paid by users that is remitted by the Company to third-party\ndevelopers is not reflected in the Company’s Consolidated\nStatements of Operations.\n\nThe Company\nrecords deferred revenue when it receives payments in advance of\nthe delivery of products or the performance of services. This\nincludes amounts that have been deferred for unspecified and\nspecified software upgrade rights and non-software services that\nare attached to hardware and software products. The Company sells\ngift cards redeemable at its retail and online stores, and also\nsells gift cards redeemable on the iTunes Store for the purchase of\ncontent and software. The Company records deferred revenue upon the\nsale of the card, which is relieved upon redemption of the card by\nthe customer. Revenue from AppleCare service and support contracts\nis deferred and recognized over the service coverage periods.\nAppleCare service and support contracts typically include extended\nphone support, repair services, web-based support resources and\ndiagnostic tools offered under the Company’s standard limited\nwarranty.\n\nThe Company\nrecords reductions to revenue for estimated commitments related to\nprice protection and for customer incentive programs, including\nreseller and end-user rebates, and other sales programs and\nvolume-based incentives. The estimated cost of these programs is\nrecognized in the period the Company has sold the product and\ncommitted to a plan. The Company also records reductions to revenue\nfor expected future product returns based on the Company’s\nhistorical experience. Revenue is recorded net of taxes collected\nfrom customers that are remitted to governmental authorities, with\nthe collected taxes recorded as current liabilities until remitted\nto the relevant government authority.\nRevenue Recognition for\nArrangements with Multiple Deliverables\n\nFor\nmulti-element arrangements that include hardware products\ncontaining software essential to the hardware product’s\nfunctionality, undelivered software elements that relate to the\nhardware product’s essential software, and undelivered\nnon-software services, the Company allocates revenue to all\ndeliverables based on their relative selling prices. In such\ncircumstances, the Company uses a hierarchy to determine the\nselling price to be used for allocating revenue to deliverables:\n(i)\xa0vendor-specific objective evidence of fair value\n(“VSOE”), (ii)\xa0third-party evidence of selling\nprice (“TPE”), and (iii)\xa0best estimate of the\nselling price (“ESP”). VSOE generally exists only when\nthe Company sells the deliverable separately and is the price\nactually charged by the Company for that deliverable. ESPs reflect\nthe Company’s best estimates of what the selling prices of\nelements would be if they were sold regularly on a stand-alone\nbasis.\n\nFor sales of\niPhone, iPad, Apple TV, for sales of iPod touch beginning in June\n2010, and for sales of Mac beginning in June 2011, the Company has\nindicated it may from time-to-time provide future unspecified\nsoftware upgrades and features to the essential software bundled\nwith each of these hardware products free of charge to customers.\nEssential software for iOS devices includes iOS and related\napplications and for Mac includes Mac OS X and iLife. In June 2011,\nthe Company announced it would provide various non-software\nservices to owners of qualifying versions of iOS devices and Mac.\nThe Company has identified up to three deliverables in arrangements\ninvolving the sale of these devices. The first deliverable is the\nhardware and software essential to the functionality of the\nhardware device delivered at the time of sale. The second\ndeliverable is the embedded right included with the purchase of iOS\ndevices, Mac and Apple TV to receive on a when-and-if-available\nbasis, future unspecified software upgrades and features relating\nto the product’s essential software. The third deliverable is\nthe non-software services to be provided to qualifying versions of\niOS devices and Mac. The Company allocates revenue between these\ndeliverables using the relative selling price method. Because the\nCompany has neither VSOE nor TPE for these deliverables, the\nallocation of revenue has been based on the Company’s ESPs.\nAmounts allocated to the delivered hardware and the related\nessential software are recognized at the time of sale provided the\nother conditions for revenue recognition have been met. Amounts\nallocated to the embedded unspecified software upgrade rights and\nthe non-software services are deferred and recognized on a\nstraight-line basis over the estimated lives of each of these\ndevices, which range from 24 to 48 months. Cost of sales related to\ndelivered hardware and related essential software, including\nestimated warranty costs, are recognized at the time of sale. Costs\nincurred to provide non-software services are recognized as cost of\nsales as incurred, and engineering and sales and marketing costs\nare recognized as operating expenses as incurred.\n\nThe\nCompany’s process for determining its ESP for deliverables\nwithout VSOE or TPE considers multiple factors that may vary\ndepending upon the unique facts and circumstances related to each\ndeliverable. The Company believes its customers, particularly\nconsumers, would be reluctant to buy unspecified software upgrade\nrights related to iOS devices, Mac and Apple TV. This view is\nprimarily based on the fact that unspecified upgrade rights do not\nobligate the Company to provide upgrades at a particular time or at\nall, and do not specify to customers which upgrades or features\nwill be delivered. The Company also believes its customers would be\nunwilling to pay a significant amount for access to the\nnon-software services because other companies offer similar\nservices at little or no cost to users. Therefore, the Company has\nconcluded that if it were to sell upgrade rights or access to the\nnon-software services on a standalone basis, including those rights\nand services attached to iOS devices, Mac and Apple TV, the selling\nprices would be relatively low. Key factors considered by the\nCompany in developing the ESPs for software upgrade rights include\nprices charged by the Company for similar offerings, market trends\nfor pricing of Mac and iOS compatible software, the Company’s\nhistorical pricing practices, the nature of the upgrade rights\n(e.g., unspecified and when-and-if-available), and the relative ESP\nof the upgrade rights as compared to the total selling price of the\nproduct. The Company may also consider, when appropriate, the\nimpact of other products and services, including advertising\nservices, on selling price assumptions when developing and\nreviewing its ESPs for software upgrade rights and related\ndeliverables. The Company may also consider additional factors as\nappropriate, including the pricing of competitive alternatives if\nthey exist and product-specific business objectives. When relevant,\nthe same factors are considered by the Company in developing ESPs\nfor offerings such as the non-software services; however, the\nprimary consideration in developing ESPs for the non-software\nservices is the estimated cost to provide such services over the\nestimated life of the related devices, including consideration for\na reasonable profit margin.\n\nBeginning with\nthe Company’s June 2011 announcement of the upcoming release\nof the non-software services and Mac OS X Lion, the Company’s\ncombined ESP for the unspecified software upgrade rights and the\nright to receive the non-software services are as follows: $16 for\niPhone and iPad, $11 for iPod touch, and $22 for Mac. The\nCompany’s ESP for the embedded unspecified software upgrade\nright included with each Apple TV is $5 for 2011 and $10 for fiscal\nyears prior to 2011. Amounts allocated to the embedded unspecified\nsoftware upgrade rights and the non-software services associated\nwith iOS devices and Apple TV are recognized on a straight-line\nbasis over 24 months, and amounts allocated to the embedded\nunspecified software upgrade rights and the non-software services\nassociated with Macs are recognized on a straight-line basis over\n48 months.\n\nThe\nCompany’s ESP for the software upgrade right included with\neach iPhone sold beginning with the introduction of iPhone in June\n2007 through the Company’s second quarter of 2010 was $25.\nBeginning in April 2010 in conjunction with the Company’s\nannouncement of iOS 4 for iPhone, the Company lowered its ESP for\nthe software upgrade right included with each iPhone to $10.\nBeginning with initial sales of iPad in April 2010, the\nCompany’s ESP for the embedded software upgrade right\nincluded with the sale of each iPad is $10, and the Company’s\nESP for the embedded software upgrade right included with each iPod\ntouch sold beginning in June 2010 is $5.\n\nThe Company\naccounts for multiple element arrangements that consist only of\nsoftware or software-related products, including the sale of\nupgrades to previously sold software, in accordance with industry\nspecific software accounting guidance. For such transactions,\nrevenue on arrangements that include multiple elements is allocated\nto each element based on the relative fair value of each element,\nand fair value is determined by VSOE. If the Company cannot\nobjectively determine the fair value of any undelivered element\nincluded in such multiple-element arrangements, the Company defers\nrevenue until all elements are delivered and services have been\nperformed, or until fair value can objectively be determined for\nany remaining undelivered elements. Beginning in July 2011, the\nsale of certain upgrades to Mac OS X and Mac versions of iLife\ninclude when-and-if-available upgrade rights for which the Company\ndoes not have VSOE. Therefore, beginning in July 2011 the Company\ndefers all revenue from the sale of upgrades to the Mac OS and Mac\nversions of iLife and recognizes it ratably over 36\nmonths.\nShipping\nCosts\n\nFor all periods\npresented, amounts billed to customers related to shipping and\nhandling are classified as revenue, and the Company’s\nshipping and handling costs are included in cost of\nsales.\nWarranty\nExpense\n\nThe Company\ngenerally provides for the estimated cost of hardware and software\nwarranties at the time the related revenue is recognized. The\nCompany assesses the adequacy of its pre-existing warranty\nliabilities and adjusts the amounts as necessary based on actual\nexperience and changes in future estimates.\nSoftware Development\nCosts\n\nResearch and\ndevelopment costs are expensed as incurred. Development costs of\ncomputer software to be sold, leased, or otherwise marketed are\nsubject to capitalization beginning when a product’s\ntechnological feasibility has been established and ending when a\nproduct is available for general release to customers. In most\ninstances, the Company’s products are released soon after\ntechnological feasibility has been established. Therefore, costs\nincurred subsequent to achievement of technological feasibility are\nusually not significant, and generally most software development\ncosts have been expensed as incurred.\n\nThe Company did\nnot capitalize any software development costs during 2011 and 2010.\nIn 2009, the Company capitalized $71 million of costs associated\nwith the development of Mac OS X Version 10.6 Snow Leopard\n(“Mac OS X Snow Leopard”), which was released during\nthe fourth quarter of 2009. The capitalized costs are being\namortized to cost of sales on a straight-line basis over a three\nyear estimated useful life of the underlying technology.\n\nTotal\namortization related to capitalized software development costs was\n$30 million, $48 million and $25 million in 2011, 2010 and 2009,\nrespectively.\nAdvertising\nCosts\n\nAdvertising\ncosts are expensed as incurred. Advertising expense was $933\nmillion, $691 million and $501 million for 2011, 2010 and 2009,\nrespectively.\nShare-based\nCompensation\n\nThe Company\nrecognizes expense related to share-based payment transactions in\nwhich it receives employee services in exchange for (a)\xa0equity\ninstruments of the Company or (b)\xa0liabilities that are based\non the fair value of the enterprise’s equity instruments or\nthat may be settled by the issuance of such equity instruments.\nShare-based compensation cost for restricted stock units\n(“RSUs”) is measured based on the closing fair market\nvalue of the Company’s common stock on the date of grant.\nShare-based compensation cost for stock options is estimated at the\ngrant date based on each option’s fair-value as calculated by\nthe Black-Scholes-Merton (“BSM”) option-pricing model.\nThe Company recognizes share-based compensation cost as expense\nratably on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period.\nThe Company recognizes a benefit from share-based compensation in\nthe Consolidated Statements of Shareholders’ Equity if an\nincremental tax benefit is realized. In addition, the Company\nrecognizes the indirect effects of share-based compensation on\nresearch and development tax credits, foreign tax credits and\ndomestic manufacturing deductions in the Consolidated Statements of\nOperations. Further information regarding share-based compensation\ncan be found in Note 6, “Shareholders’ Equity and\nShare-based Compensation” of this Form 10-K.\nIncome\nTaxes\n\nThe provision\nfor income taxes is computed using the asset and liability method,\nunder which deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for\nthe expected future tax consequences of temporary differences\nbetween the financial reporting and tax bases of assets and\nliabilities, and for operating losses and tax credit carryforwards.\nDeferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using the\ncurrently enacted tax rates that apply to taxable income in effect\nfor the years in which those tax assets are expected to be realized\nor settled. The Company records a valuation allowance to reduce\ndeferred tax assets to the amount that is believed more likely than\nnot to be realized.\n\nThe Company\nrecognizes the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if\nit is more likely than not the tax position will be sustained on\nexamination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical\nmerits of the position. The tax benefits recognized in the\nfinancial statements from such positions are then measured based on\nthe largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being\nrealized upon settlement. See Note 5, “Income Taxes” of\nthis Form 10-K for additional information.\nEarnings Per Common\nShare\n\nBasic earnings\nper common share is computed by dividing income available to common\nshareholders by the weighted-average number of shares of common\nstock outstanding during the period. Diluted earnings per common\nshare is computed by dividing income available to common\nshareholders by the weighted-average number of shares of common\nstock outstanding during the period increased to include the number\nof additional shares of common stock that would have been\noutstanding if the potentially dilutive securities had been issued.\nPotentially dilutive securities include outstanding stock options,\nshares to be purchased under the employee stock purchase plan and\nunvested RSUs. The dilutive effect of potentially dilutive\nsecurities is reflected in diluted earnings per common share by\napplication of the treasury stock method. Under the treasury stock\nmethod, an increase in the fair market value of the Company’s\ncommon stock can result in a greater dilutive effect from\npotentially dilutive securities.\n\nThe following\ntable sets forth the computation of basic and diluted earnings per\ncommon share for the three years ended September\xa024, 2011 (in\nthousands, except net income in millions and per share\namounts):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2009\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nNumerator:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNet income\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n25,922\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n14,013\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n8,235\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDenominator:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nWeighted-average shares\noutstanding\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n924,258\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n909,461\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n893,016\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nEffect of dilutive\nsecurities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n12,387\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n15,251\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n13,989\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nWeighted-average diluted\nshares\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n936,645\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n924,712\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n907,005\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\nBasic earnings per common\nshare\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n28.05\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n15.41\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n9.22\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDiluted earnings per common\nshare\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n27.68\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n15.15\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n9.08\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nPotentially\ndilutive securities representing 1.7\xa0million, 1.6\xa0million\nand 12.6\xa0million shares of common stock for 2011, 2010 and\n2009, respectively, were excluded from the computation of diluted\nearnings per common share for these periods because their effect\nwould have been antidilutive.\n\n\xa0\nFinancial\nInstruments\nCash Equivalents and\nMarketable Securities\n\nAll highly\nliquid investments with maturities of three months or less at the\ndate of purchase are classified as cash equivalents. The\nCompany’s marketable debt and equity securities have been\nclassified and accounted for as available-for-sale. Management\ndetermines the appropriate classification of its investments at the\ntime of purchase and reevaluates the designations at each balance\nsheet date. The Company classifies its marketable debt securities\nas either short-term or long-term based on each instrument’s\nunderlying contractual maturity date. Marketable debt securities\nwith maturities of 12 months or less are classified as short-term\nand marketable debt securities with maturities greater than 12\nmonths are classified as long-term. The Company classifies its\nmarketable equity securities, including mutual funds, as either\nshort-term or long-term based on the nature of each security and\nits availability for use in current operations. The Company’s\nmarketable debt and equity securities are carried at fair value,\nwith the unrealized gains and losses, net of taxes, reported as a\ncomponent of shareholders’ equity. The cost of securities\nsold is based upon the specific identification method.\nDerivative Financial\nInstruments\n\nThe Company\naccounts for its derivative instruments as either assets or\nliabilities and carries them at fair value.\n\nFor derivative\ninstruments that hedge the exposure to variability in expected\nfuture cash flows that are designated as cash flow hedges, the\neffective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative instrument\nis reported as a component of accumulated other comprehensive\nincome (“AOCI”) in shareholders’ equity and\nreclassified into income in the same period or periods during which\nthe hedged transaction affects earnings. The ineffective portion of\nthe gain or loss on the derivative instrument, if any, is\nrecognized in current income. To receive hedge accounting\ntreatment, cash flow hedges must be highly effective in offsetting\nchanges to expected future cash flows on hedged transactions. For\noptions designated as cash flow hedges, changes in the time value\nare excluded from the assessment of hedge effectiveness and are\nrecognized in income. For derivative instruments that hedge the\nexposure to changes in the fair value of an asset or a liability\nand that are designated as fair value hedges, both the net gain or\nloss on the derivative instrument as well as the offsetting gain or\nloss on the hedged item attributable to the hedged risk are\nrecognized in earnings in the current period. The Company had no\nfair value hedges in 2011, 2010 and 2009. The net gain or loss on\nthe effective portion of a derivative instrument that is designated\nas an economic hedge of the foreign currency translation exposure\nof the net investment in a foreign operation is reported in the\nsame manner as a foreign currency translation adjustment. For\nforward exchange contracts designated as net investment hedges, the\nCompany excludes changes in fair value relating to changes in the\nforward carry component from its definition of effectiveness.\nAccordingly, any gains or losses related to this component are\nrecognized in current income. Derivatives that do not qualify as\nhedges must be adjusted to fair value through current\nincome.\nAllowance for Doubtful\nAccounts\n\nThe Company\nrecords its allowance for doubtful accounts based upon its\nassessment of various factors. The Company considers historical\nexperience, the age of the accounts receivable balances, credit\nquality of the Company’s customers, current economic\nconditions, and other factors that may affect customers’\nability to pay.\nInventories\n\nInventories are\nstated at the lower of cost, computed using the first-in, first-out\nmethod, or market. If the cost of the inventories exceeds their\nmarket value, provisions are made currently for the difference\nbetween the cost and the market value. The Company’s\ninventories consist primarily of components and finished goods for\nall periods presented.\n\n\xa0\nProperty, Plant and\nEquipment\n\nProperty, plant\nand equipment are stated at cost. Depreciation is computed by use\nof the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the\nassets, which for buildings is the lesser of 30 years or the\nremaining life of the underlying building, up to five years for\nequipment, and the shorter of lease terms or ten years for\nleasehold improvements. The Company capitalizes eligible costs to\nacquire or develop internal-use software that are incurred\nsubsequent to the preliminary project stage. Capitalized costs\nrelated to internal-use software are amortized using the\nstraight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets,\nwhich range from three to five years. Depreciation and amortization\nexpense on property and equipment was $1.6 billion, $815 million\nand $606 million during 2011, 2010 and 2009,\nrespectively.\nLong-Lived Assets\nIncluding Goodwill and Other Acquired Intangible\nAssets\n\nThe Company\nreviews property, plant and equipment and certain identifiable\nintangibles, excluding goodwill, for impairment. Long-lived assets\nare reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in\ncircumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be\nrecoverable. Recoverability of these assets is measured by\ncomparison of their carrying amounts to future undiscounted cash\nflows the assets are expected to generate. If property, plant and\nequipment and certain identifiable intangibles are considered to be\nimpaired, the impairment to be recognized equals the amount by\nwhich the carrying value of the assets exceeds its fair market\nvalue. The Company did not record any significant impairments\nduring 2011, 2010 and 2009.\n\nThe Company\ndoes not amortize goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite\nuseful lives, rather such assets are required to be tested for\nimpairment at least annually or sooner whenever events or changes\nin circumstances indicate that the assets may be impaired. The\nCompany performs its goodwill and intangible asset impairment tests\nin the fourth quarter of each fiscal year. The Company did not\nrecognize any goodwill or intangible asset impairment charges in\n2011, 2010 and 2009. The Company established reporting units based\non its current reporting structure. For purposes of testing\ngoodwill for impairment, goodwill has been allocated to these\nreporting units to the extent it relates to each reporting\nunit.\n\nThe Company\namortizes its intangible assets with definite lives over their\nestimated useful lives and reviews these assets for impairment. The\nCompany is currently amortizing its acquired intangible assets with\ndefinite lives over periods generally ranging between three to\nseven years.\nFair Value\nMeasurements\n\nThe Company\napplies fair value accounting for all financial assets and\nliabilities and non-financial assets and liabilities that are\nrecognized or disclosed at fair value in the financial statements\non a recurring basis. The Company defines fair value as the price\nthat would be received from selling an asset or paid to transfer a\nliability in an orderly transaction between market participants at\nthe measurement date. When determining the fair value measurements\nfor assets and liabilities, which are required to be recorded at\nfair value, the Company considers the principal or most\nadvantageous market in which the Company would transact and the\nmarket-based risk measurements or assumptions that market\nparticipants would use in pricing the asset or liability, such as\nrisks inherent in valuation techniques, transfer restrictions and\ncredit risk. Fair value is estimated by applying the following\nhierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value\ninto three levels and bases the categorization within the hierarchy\nupon the lowest level of input that is available and significant to\nthe fair value measurement:\n\nLevel 1\n– Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or\nliabilities.\n\nLevel 2\n– Observable inputs other than quoted prices in active\nmarkets for identical assets and liabilities, quoted prices for\nidentical or similar assets or liabilities in inactive markets, or\nother inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by\nobservable market data for substantially the full term of the\nassets or liabilities.\n\n\xa0\n\nLevel 3\n– Inputs that are generally unobservable and typically\nreflect management’s estimate of assumptions that market\nparticipants would use in pricing the asset or\nliability.\n\nThe\nCompany’s valuation techniques used to measure the fair value\nof money market funds and certain marketable equity securities were\nderived from quoted prices in active markets for identical assets\nor liabilities. The valuation techniques used to measure the fair\nvalue of all other financial instruments, all of which have\ncounterparties with high credit ratings, were valued based on\nquoted market prices or model driven valuations using significant\ninputs derived from or corroborated by observable market\ndata.\n\nIn accordance\nwith the fair value accounting requirements, companies may choose\nto measure eligible financial instruments and certain other items\nat fair value. The Company has not elected the fair value option\nfor any eligible financial instruments.\nForeign Currency\nTranslation and Remeasurement\n\nThe Company\ntranslates the assets and liabilities of its non-U.S. dollar\nfunctional currency subsidiaries into U.S. dollars using exchange\nrates in effect at the end of each period. Revenue and expenses for\nthese subsidiaries are translated using rates that approximate\nthose in effect during the period. Gains and losses from these\ntranslations are recognized in foreign currency translation\nincluded in accumulated other comprehensive income in\nshareholders’ equity. The Company’s subsidiaries that\nuse the U.S. dollar as their functional currency remeasure monetary\nassets and liabilities at exchange rates in effect at the end of\neach period, and inventories, property, and nonmonetary assets and\nliabilities at historical rates. Gains and losses from these\nremeasurements were insignificant and have been included in the\nCompany’s results of operations.\nSegment\nInformation\n\nThe Company\nreports segment information based on the “management”\napproach. The management approach designates the internal reporting\nused by management for making decisions and assessing performance\nas the source of the Company’s reportable segments.\nInformation about the Company’s products, major customers and\ngeographic areas on a company-wide basis is also\ndisclosed.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '2011', '', '', '2010', '', '', '2009', '', 'Numerator:', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Net income', '', '$', '25,922', '', '', '$', '14,013', '', '', '$', '8,235', '', 'Denominator:', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Weighted-average shares\noutstanding', '', '', '924,258', '', '', '', '909,461', '', '', '', '893,016', '', 'Effect of dilutive\nsecurities', '', '', '12,387', '', '', '', '15,251', '', '', '', '13,989', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Weighted-average diluted\nshares', '', '', '936,645', '', '', '', '924,712', '', '', '', '907,005', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Basic earnings per common\nshare', '', '$', '28.05', '', '', '$', '15.41', '', '', '$', '9.22', '', '', '', '', '', 'Diluted earnings per common\nshare', '', '$', '27.68', '', '', '$', '15.15', '', '', '$', '9.08', '']

['Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Policies)', '12 Months Ended']
['Sep. 24, 2011']
['Basis of Presentation and Preparation', 'Basis of Presentation and\nPreparation\n\nThe accompanying\nconsolidated financial statements include the accounts of the\nCompany. Intercompany accounts and transactions have been\neliminated. The preparation of these consolidated financial\nstatements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting\nprinciples (“GAAP”) requires management to make\nestimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in these\nconsolidated financial statements and accompanying notes. Actual\nresults could differ materially from those estimates. Certain prior\nyear amounts in the consolidated financial statements and notes\nthereto have been reclassified to conform to the current\nyear’s presentation.\n\nThe\nCompany’s fiscal year is the 52 or 53-week period that ends\non the last Saturday of September. The Company’s fiscal years\n2011, 2010 and 2009 ended on September\xa024,\n2011,\xa0September\xa025, 2010 and September\xa026, 2009,\nrespectively, and included 52 weeks each. An additional week is\nincluded in the first fiscal quarter approximately every six years\nto realign fiscal quarters with calendar quarters. Fiscal year 2012\nwill end on September\xa029, 2012, and will span 53 weeks, with a\n14th week added to the first quarter of 2012. Unless otherwise\nstated, references to particular years or quarters refer to the\nCompany’s fiscal years ended in September and the associated\nquarters of those fiscal years.\n\nDuring the first\nquarter of 2011, the Company adopted the Financial Accounting\nStandard Board’s (“FASB”) new accounting\nstandard\xa0on consolidation of variable interest\nentities.\xa0This new accounting standard eliminates the\nmandatory quantitative approach in determining control\nfor\xa0evaluating whether variable interest entities need to be\nconsolidated\xa0in favor of a qualitative analysis, and requires\nan ongoing reassessment\xa0of control over such entities. The\nadoption of this new accounting standard did not impact the\nCompany’s consolidated financial statements.']
['Revenue Recognition, Policy', 'Revenue\nRecognition\n\nNet sales\nconsist primarily of revenue from the sale of hardware, software,\ndigital content and applications, peripherals, and service and\nsupport contracts. The Company recognizes revenue when persuasive\nevidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred, the sales\nprice is fixed or determinable, and collection is probable. Product\nis considered delivered to the customer once it has been shipped\nand title and risk of loss have been transferred. For most of the\nCompany’s product sales, these criteria are met at the time\nthe product is shipped. For online sales to individuals, for some\nsales to education customers in the U.S., and for certain other\nsales, the Company defers revenue until the customer receives the\nproduct because the Company legally retains a portion of the risk\nof loss on these sales during transit. The Company recognizes\nrevenue from the sale of hardware products, software bundled with\nhardware that is essential to the functionality of the hardware,\nand third-party digital content sold on the iTunes Store in\naccordance with general revenue recognition accounting guidance.\nThe Company recognizes revenue in accordance with industry specific\nsoftware accounting guidance for the following types of sales\ntransactions: (i)\xa0standalone sales of software products,\n(ii)\xa0sales of software upgrades and (iii)\xa0sales of\nsoftware bundled with hardware not essential to the functionality\nof the hardware.\n\n\xa0\n\nThe Company\nsells software and peripheral products obtained from other\ncompanies. The Company generally establishes its own pricing and\nretains related inventory risk, is the primary obligor in sales\ntransactions with its customers, and assumes the credit risk for\namounts billed to its customers. Accordingly, the Company generally\nrecognizes revenue for the sale of products obtained from other\ncompanies based on the gross amount billed. For sales of\nthird-party software applications for iPhone, iPad and iPod touch\n(“iOS devices”) and Macs made through the App Store and\nthe Mac App Store, the Company is not the primary obligor to users\nof the software, and third- party developers determine the selling\nprice of their software. Therefore, the Company accounts for such\nsales on a net basis by recognizing only the commission it retains\nfrom each sale and including that commission in net sales in the\nConsolidated Statements of Operations. The portion of the sales\nprice paid by users that is remitted by the Company to third-party\ndevelopers is not reflected in the Company’s Consolidated\nStatements of Operations.\n\nThe Company\nrecords deferred revenue when it receives payments in advance of\nthe delivery of products or the performance of services. This\nincludes amounts that have been deferred for unspecified and\nspecified software upgrade rights and non-software services that\nare attached to hardware and software products. The Company sells\ngift cards redeemable at its retail and online stores, and also\nsells gift cards redeemable on the iTunes Store for the purchase of\ncontent and software. The Company records deferred revenue upon the\nsale of the card, which is relieved upon redemption of the card by\nthe customer. Revenue from AppleCare service and support contracts\nis deferred and recognized over the service coverage periods.\nAppleCare service and support contracts typically include extended\nphone support, repair services, web-based support resources and\ndiagnostic tools offered under the Company’s standard limited\nwarranty.\n\nThe Company\nrecords reductions to revenue for estimated commitments related to\nprice protection and for customer incentive programs, including\nreseller and end-user rebates, and other sales programs and\nvolume-based incentives. The estimated cost of these programs is\nrecognized in the period the Company has sold the product and\ncommitted to a plan. The Company also records reductions to revenue\nfor expected future product returns based on the Company’s\nhistorical experience. Revenue is recorded net of taxes collected\nfrom customers that are remitted to governmental authorities, with\nthe collected taxes recorded as current liabilities until remitted\nto the relevant government authority.\nRevenue Recognition for\nArrangements with Multiple Deliverables\n\nFor\nmulti-element arrangements that include hardware products\ncontaining software essential to the hardware product’s\nfunctionality, undelivered software elements that relate to the\nhardware product’s essential software, and undelivered\nnon-software services, the Company allocates revenue to all\ndeliverables based on their relative selling prices. In such\ncircumstances, the Company uses a hierarchy to determine the\nselling price to be used for allocating revenue to deliverables:\n(i)\xa0vendor-specific objective evidence of fair value\n(“VSOE”), (ii)\xa0third-party evidence of selling\nprice (“TPE”), and (iii)\xa0best estimate of the\nselling price (“ESP”). VSOE generally exists only when\nthe Company sells the deliverable separately and is the price\nactually charged by the Company for that deliverable. ESPs reflect\nthe Company’s best estimates of what the selling prices of\nelements would be if they were sold regularly on a stand-alone\nbasis.\n\nFor sales of\niPhone, iPad, Apple TV, for sales of iPod touch beginning in June\n2010, and for sales of Mac beginning in June 2011, the Company has\nindicated it may from time-to-time provide future unspecified\nsoftware upgrades and features to the essential software bundled\nwith each of these hardware products free of charge to customers.\nEssential software for iOS devices includes iOS and related\napplications and for Mac includes Mac OS X and iLife. In June 2011,\nthe Company announced it would provide various non-software\nservices to owners of qualifying versions of iOS devices and Mac.\nThe Company has identified up to three deliverables in arrangements\ninvolving the sale of these devices. The first deliverable is the\nhardware and software essential to the functionality of the\nhardware device delivered at the time of sale. The second\ndeliverable is the embedded right included with the purchase of iOS\ndevices, Mac and Apple TV to receive on a when-and-if-available\nbasis, future unspecified software upgrades and features relating\nto the product’s essential software. The third deliverable is\nthe non-software services to be provided to qualifying versions of\niOS devices and Mac. The Company allocates revenue between these\ndeliverables using the relative selling price method. Because the\nCompany has neither VSOE nor TPE for these deliverables, the\nallocation of revenue has been based on the Company’s ESPs.\nAmounts allocated to the delivered hardware and the related\nessential software are recognized at the time of sale provided the\nother conditions for revenue recognition have been met. Amounts\nallocated to the embedded unspecified software upgrade rights and\nthe non-software services are deferred and recognized on a\nstraight-line basis over the estimated lives of each of these\ndevices, which range from 24 to 48 months. Cost of sales related to\ndelivered hardware and related essential software, including\nestimated warranty costs, are recognized at the time of sale. Costs\nincurred to provide non-software services are recognized as cost of\nsales as incurred, and engineering and sales and marketing costs\nare recognized as operating expenses as incurred.\n\nThe\nCompany’s process for determining its ESP for deliverables\nwithout VSOE or TPE considers multiple factors that may vary\ndepending upon the unique facts and circumstances related to each\ndeliverable. The Company believes its customers, particularly\nconsumers, would be reluctant to buy unspecified software upgrade\nrights related to iOS devices, Mac and Apple TV. This view is\nprimarily based on the fact that unspecified upgrade rights do not\nobligate the Company to provide upgrades at a particular time or at\nall, and do not specify to customers which upgrades or features\nwill be delivered. The Company also believes its customers would be\nunwilling to pay a significant amount for access to the\nnon-software services because other companies offer similar\nservices at little or no cost to users. Therefore, the Company has\nconcluded that if it were to sell upgrade rights or access to the\nnon-software services on a standalone basis, including those rights\nand services attached to iOS devices, Mac and Apple TV, the selling\nprices would be relatively low. Key factors considered by the\nCompany in developing the ESPs for software upgrade rights include\nprices charged by the Company for similar offerings, market trends\nfor pricing of Mac and iOS compatible software, the Company’s\nhistorical pricing practices, the nature of the upgrade rights\n(e.g., unspecified and when-and-if-available), and the relative ESP\nof the upgrade rights as compared to the total selling price of the\nproduct. The Company may also consider, when appropriate, the\nimpact of other products and services, including advertising\nservices, on selling price assumptions when developing and\nreviewing its ESPs for software upgrade rights and related\ndeliverables. The Company may also consider additional factors as\nappropriate, including the pricing of competitive alternatives if\nthey exist and product-specific business objectives. When relevant,\nthe same factors are considered by the Company in developing ESPs\nfor offerings such as the non-software services; however, the\nprimary consideration in developing ESPs for the non-software\nservices is the estimated cost to provide such services over the\nestimated life of the related devices, including consideration for\na reasonable profit margin.\n\nBeginning with\nthe Company’s June 2011 announcement of the upcoming release\nof the non-software services and Mac OS X Lion, the Company’s\ncombined ESP for the unspecified software upgrade rights and the\nright to receive the non-software services are as follows: $16 for\niPhone and iPad, $11 for iPod touch, and $22 for Mac. The\nCompany’s ESP for the embedded unspecified software upgrade\nright included with each Apple TV is $5 for 2011 and $10 for fiscal\nyears prior to 2011. Amounts allocated to the embedded unspecified\nsoftware upgrade rights and the non-software services associated\nwith iOS devices and Apple TV are recognized on a straight-line\nbasis over 24 months, and amounts allocated to the embedded\nunspecified software upgrade rights and the non-software services\nassociated with Macs are recognized on a straight-line basis over\n48 months.\n\nThe\nCompany’s ESP for the software upgrade right included with\neach iPhone sold beginning with the introduction of iPhone in June\n2007 through the Company’s second quarter of 2010 was $25.\nBeginning in April 2010 in conjunction with the Company’s\nannouncement of iOS 4 for iPhone, the Company lowered its ESP for\nthe software upgrade right included with each iPhone to $10.\nBeginning with initial sales of iPad in April 2010, the\nCompany’s ESP for the embedded software upgrade right\nincluded with the sale of each iPad is $10, and the Company’s\nESP for the embedded software upgrade right included with each iPod\ntouch sold beginning in June 2010 is $5.\n\nThe Company\naccounts for multiple element arrangements that consist only of\nsoftware or software-related products, including the sale of\nupgrades to previously sold software, in accordance with industry\nspecific software accounting guidance. For such transactions,\nrevenue on arrangements that include multiple elements is allocated\nto each element based on the relative fair value of each element,\nand fair value is determined by VSOE. If the Company cannot\nobjectively determine the fair value of any undelivered element\nincluded in such multiple-element arrangements, the Company defers\nrevenue until all elements are delivered and services have been\nperformed, or until fair value can objectively be determined for\nany remaining undelivered elements. Beginning in July 2011, the\nsale of certain upgrades to Mac OS X and Mac versions of iLife\ninclude when-and-if-available upgrade rights for which the Company\ndoes not have VSOE. Therefore, beginning in July 2011 the Company\ndefers all revenue from the sale of upgrades to the Mac OS and Mac\nversions of iLife and recognizes it ratably over 36\nmonths.']
['Shipping Costs, Policy', 'Shipping\nCosts\n\nFor all periods\npresented, amounts billed to customers related to shipping and\nhandling are classified as revenue, and the Company’s\nshipping and handling costs are included in cost of\nsales.']
['Warranty Expense, Policy', 'Warranty\nExpense\n\nThe Company\ngenerally provides for the estimated cost of hardware and software\nwarranties at the time the related revenue is recognized. The\nCompany assesses the adequacy of its pre-existing warranty\nliabilities and adjusts the amounts as necessary based on actual\nexperience and changes in future estimates.']
['Software Development Costs, Policy', 'Software Development\nCosts\n\nResearch and\ndevelopment costs are expensed as incurred. Development costs of\ncomputer software to be sold, leased, or otherwise marketed are\nsubject to capitalization beginning when a product’s\ntechnological feasibility has been established and ending when a\nproduct is available for general release to customers. In most\ninstances, the Company’s products are released soon after\ntechnological feasibility has been established. Therefore, costs\nincurred subsequent to achievement of technological feasibility are\nusually not significant, and generally most software development\ncosts have been expensed as incurred.\n\nThe Company did\nnot capitalize any software development costs during 2011 and 2010.\nIn 2009, the Company capitalized $71 million of costs associated\nwith the development of Mac OS X Version 10.6 Snow Leopard\n(“Mac OS X Snow Leopard”), which was released during\nthe fourth quarter of 2009. The capitalized costs are being\namortized to cost of sales on a straight-line basis over a three\nyear estimated useful life of the underlying technology.\n\nTotal\namortization related to capitalized software development costs was\n$30 million, $48 million and $25 million in 2011, 2010 and 2009,\nrespectively.']
['Advertising Costs, Policy', 'Advertising\nCosts\n\nAdvertising\ncosts are expensed as incurred. Advertising expense was $933\nmillion, $691 million and $501 million for 2011, 2010 and 2009,\nrespectively.']
['Share-Based Compensation, Policy', 'Share-based\nCompensation\n\nThe Company\nrecognizes expense related to share-based payment transactions in\nwhich it receives employee services in exchange for (a)\xa0equity\ninstruments of the Company or (b)\xa0liabilities that are based\non the fair value of the enterprise’s equity instruments or\nthat may be settled by the issuance of such equity instruments.\nShare-based compensation cost for restricted stock units\n(“RSUs”) is measured based on the closing fair market\nvalue of the Company’s common stock on the date of grant.\nShare-based compensation cost for stock options is estimated at the\ngrant date based on each option’s fair-value as calculated by\nthe Black-Scholes-Merton (“BSM”) option-pricing model.\nThe Company recognizes share-based compensation cost as expense\nratably on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period.\nThe Company recognizes a benefit from share-based compensation in\nthe Consolidated Statements of Shareholders’ Equity if an\nincremental tax benefit is realized. In addition, the Company\nrecognizes the indirect effects of share-based compensation on\nresearch and development tax credits, foreign tax credits and\ndomestic manufacturing deductions in the Consolidated Statements of\nOperations. Further information regarding share-based compensation\ncan be found in Note 6, “Shareholders’ Equity and\nShare-based Compensation” of this Form 10-K.']
['Income Taxes, Policy', 'Income\nTaxes\n\nThe provision\nfor income taxes is computed using the asset and liability method,\nunder which deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for\nthe expected future tax consequences of temporary differences\nbetween the financial reporting and tax bases of assets and\nliabilities, and for operating losses and tax credit carryforwards.\nDeferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using the\ncurrently enacted tax rates that apply to taxable income in effect\nfor the years in which those tax assets are expected to be realized\nor settled. The Company records a valuation allowance to reduce\ndeferred tax assets to the amount that is believed more likely than\nnot to be realized.\n\nThe Company\nrecognizes the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if\nit is more likely than not the tax position will be sustained on\nexamination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical\nmerits of the position. The tax benefits recognized in the\nfinancial statements from such positions are then measured based on\nthe largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being\nrealized upon settlement. See Note 5, “Income Taxes” of\nthis Form 10-K for additional information.']
['Earnings Per Common Share, Policy', 'Earnings Per Common\nShare\n\nBasic earnings\nper common share is computed by dividing income available to common\nshareholders by the weighted-average number of shares of common\nstock outstanding during the period. Diluted earnings per common\nshare is computed by dividing income available to common\nshareholders by the weighted-average number of shares of common\nstock outstanding during the period increased to include the number\nof additional shares of common stock that would have been\noutstanding if the potentially dilutive securities had been issued.\nPotentially dilutive securities include outstanding stock options,\nshares to be purchased under the employee stock purchase plan and\nunvested RSUs. The dilutive effect of potentially dilutive\nsecurities is reflected in diluted earnings per common share by\napplication of the treasury stock method. Under the treasury stock\nmethod, an increase in the fair market value of the Company’s\ncommon stock can result in a greater dilutive effect from\npotentially dilutive securities.']
['Cash Equivalents and Marketable Securities, Policy', 'Cash Equivalents and\nMarketable Securities\n\nAll highly\nliquid investments with maturities of three months or less at the\ndate of purchase are classified as cash equivalents. The\nCompany’s marketable debt and equity securities have been\nclassified and accounted for as available-for-sale. Management\ndetermines the appropriate classification of its investments at the\ntime of purchase and reevaluates the designations at each balance\nsheet date. The Company classifies its marketable debt securities\nas either short-term or long-term based on each instrument’s\nunderlying contractual maturity date. Marketable debt securities\nwith maturities of 12 months or less are classified as short-term\nand marketable debt securities with maturities greater than 12\nmonths are classified as long-term. The Company classifies its\nmarketable equity securities, including mutual funds, as either\nshort-term or long-term based on the nature of each security and\nits availability for use in current operations. The Company’s\nmarketable debt and equity securities are carried at fair value,\nwith the unrealized gains and losses, net of taxes, reported as a\ncomponent of shareholders’ equity. The cost of securities\nsold is based upon the specific identification method.']
['Derivative Financial Instruments, Policy', 'Derivative Financial\nInstruments\n\nThe Company\naccounts for its derivative instruments as either assets or\nliabilities and carries them at fair value.\n\nFor derivative\ninstruments that hedge the exposure to variability in expected\nfuture cash flows that are designated as cash flow hedges, the\neffective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative instrument\nis reported as a component of accumulated other comprehensive\nincome (“AOCI”) in shareholders’ equity and\nreclassified into income in the same period or periods during which\nthe hedged transaction affects earnings. The ineffective portion of\nthe gain or loss on the derivative instrument, if any, is\nrecognized in current income. To receive hedge accounting\ntreatment, cash flow hedges must be highly effective in offsetting\nchanges to expected future cash flows on hedged transactions. For\noptions designated as cash flow hedges, changes in the time value\nare excluded from the assessment of hedge effectiveness and are\nrecognized in income. For derivative instruments that hedge the\nexposure to changes in the fair value of an asset or a liability\nand that are designated as fair value hedges, both the net gain or\nloss on the derivative instrument as well as the offsetting gain or\nloss on the hedged item attributable to the hedged risk are\nrecognized in earnings in the current period. The Company had no\nfair value hedges in 2011, 2010 and 2009. The net gain or loss on\nthe effective portion of a derivative instrument that is designated\nas an economic hedge of the foreign currency translation exposure\nof the net investment in a foreign operation is reported in the\nsame manner as a foreign currency translation adjustment. For\nforward exchange contracts designated as net investment hedges, the\nCompany excludes changes in fair value relating to changes in the\nforward carry component from its definition of effectiveness.\nAccordingly, any gains or losses related to this component are\nrecognized in current income. Derivatives that do not qualify as\nhedges must be adjusted to fair value through current\nincome.']
['Allowance For Doubtful Accounts, Policy', 'Allowance for Doubtful\nAccounts\n\nThe Company\nrecords its allowance for doubtful accounts based upon its\nassessment of various factors. The Company considers historical\nexperience, the age of the accounts receivable balances, credit\nquality of the Company’s customers, current economic\nconditions, and other factors that may affect customers’\nability to pay.']
['Inventories, Policy', 'Inventories\n\nInventories are\nstated at the lower of cost, computed using the first-in, first-out\nmethod, or market. If the cost of the inventories exceeds their\nmarket value, provisions are made currently for the difference\nbetween the cost and the market value. The Company’s\ninventories consist primarily of components and finished goods for\nall periods presented.']
['Property, Plant and Equipment, Policy', 'Property, Plant and\nEquipment\n\nProperty, plant\nand equipment are stated at cost. Depreciation is computed by use\nof the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the\nassets, which for buildings is the lesser of 30 years or the\nremaining life of the underlying building, up to five years for\nequipment, and the shorter of lease terms or ten years for\nleasehold improvements. The Company capitalizes eligible costs to\nacquire or develop internal-use software that are incurred\nsubsequent to the preliminary project stage. Capitalized costs\nrelated to internal-use software are amortized using the\nstraight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets,\nwhich range from three to five years. Depreciation and amortization\nexpense on property and equipment was $1.6 billion, $815 million\nand $606 million during 2011, 2010 and 2009,\nrespectively.']
['Long-Lived Assets Including Goodwill and Other Acquired Intangible Asset, Policy', 'Long-Lived Assets\nIncluding Goodwill and Other Acquired Intangible\nAssets\n\nThe Company\nreviews property, plant and equipment and certain identifiable\nintangibles, excluding goodwill, for impairment. Long-lived assets\nare reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in\ncircumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be\nrecoverable. Recoverability of these assets is measured by\ncomparison of their carrying amounts to future undiscounted cash\nflows the assets are expected to generate. If property, plant and\nequipment and certain identifiable intangibles are considered to be\nimpaired, the impairment to be recognized equals the amount by\nwhich the carrying value of the assets exceeds its fair market\nvalue. The Company did not record any significant impairments\nduring 2011, 2010 and 2009.\n\nThe Company\ndoes not amortize goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite\nuseful lives, rather such assets are required to be tested for\nimpairment at least annually or sooner whenever events or changes\nin circumstances indicate that the assets may be impaired. The\nCompany performs its goodwill and intangible asset impairment tests\nin the fourth quarter of each fiscal year. The Company did not\nrecognize any goodwill or intangible asset impairment charges in\n2011, 2010 and 2009. The Company established reporting units based\non its current reporting structure. For purposes of testing\ngoodwill for impairment, goodwill has been allocated to these\nreporting units to the extent it relates to each reporting\nunit.\n\nThe Company\namortizes its intangible assets with definite lives over their\nestimated useful lives and reviews these assets for impairment. The\nCompany is currently amortizing its acquired intangible assets with\ndefinite lives over periods generally ranging between three to\nseven years.']
['Fair Value Measurements, Policy', 'Fair Value\nMeasurements\n\nThe Company\napplies fair value accounting for all financial assets and\nliabilities and non-financial assets and liabilities that are\nrecognized or disclosed at fair value in the financial statements\non a recurring basis. The Company defines fair value as the price\nthat would be received from selling an asset or paid to transfer a\nliability in an orderly transaction between market participants at\nthe measurement date. When determining the fair value measurements\nfor assets and liabilities, which are required to be recorded at\nfair value, the Company considers the principal or most\nadvantageous market in which the Company would transact and the\nmarket-based risk measurements or assumptions that market\nparticipants would use in pricing the asset or liability, such as\nrisks inherent in valuation techniques, transfer restrictions and\ncredit risk. Fair value is estimated by applying the following\nhierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value\ninto three levels and bases the categorization within the hierarchy\nupon the lowest level of input that is available and significant to\nthe fair value measurement:\n\nLevel 1\n– Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or\nliabilities.\n\nLevel 2\n– Observable inputs other than quoted prices in active\nmarkets for identical assets and liabilities, quoted prices for\nidentical or similar assets or liabilities in inactive markets, or\nother inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by\nobservable market data for substantially the full term of the\nassets or liabilities.\n\n\xa0\n\nLevel 3\n– Inputs that are generally unobservable and typically\nreflect management’s estimate of assumptions that market\nparticipants would use in pricing the asset or\nliability.\n\nThe\nCompany’s valuation techniques used to measure the fair value\nof money market funds and certain marketable equity securities were\nderived from quoted prices in active markets for identical assets\nor liabilities. The valuation techniques used to measure the fair\nvalue of all other financial instruments, all of which have\ncounterparties with high credit ratings, were valued based on\nquoted market prices or model driven valuations using significant\ninputs derived from or corroborated by observable market\ndata.\n\nIn accordance\nwith the fair value accounting requirements, companies may choose\nto measure eligible financial instruments and certain other items\nat fair value. The Company has not elected the fair value option\nfor any eligible financial instruments.']
['Foreign Currency Translation and Remeasurement, Policy', 'Foreign Currency\nTranslation and Remeasurement\n\nThe Company\ntranslates the assets and liabilities of its non-U.S. dollar\nfunctional currency subsidiaries into U.S. dollars using exchange\nrates in effect at the end of each period. Revenue and expenses for\nthese subsidiaries are translated using rates that approximate\nthose in effect during the period. Gains and losses from these\ntranslations are recognized in foreign currency translation\nincluded in accumulated other comprehensive income in\nshareholders’ equity. The Company’s subsidiaries that\nuse the U.S. dollar as their functional currency remeasure monetary\nassets and liabilities at exchange rates in effect at the end of\neach period, and inventories, property, and nonmonetary assets and\nliabilities at historical rates. Gains and losses from these\nremeasurements were insignificant and have been included in the\nCompany’s results of operations.']
['Segment Information, Policy', 'Segment\nInformation\n\nThe Company\nreports segment information based on the “management”\napproach. The management approach designates the internal reporting\nused by management for making decisions and assessing performance\nas the source of the Company’s reportable segments.\nInformation about the Company’s products, major customers and\ngeographic areas on a company-wide basis is also\ndisclosed.']
['Derivatives, Policy', 'Derivative Financial\nInstruments\n\nThe Company\nuses derivatives to partially offset its business exposure to\nforeign currency exchange risk. The Company may enter into foreign\ncurrency forward and option contracts to offset some of the foreign\nexchange risk on expected future cash flows on certain forecasted\nrevenue and cost of sales, on net investments in certain foreign\nsubsidiaries, and on certain existing assets and\nliabilities.\n\nTo help protect\ngross margins from fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates,\ncertain of the Company’s subsidiaries whose functional\ncurrency is the U.S. dollar hedge a portion of forecasted foreign\ncurrency revenue. The Company’s subsidiaries whose functional\ncurrency is not the U.S. dollar and who sell in local currencies\nmay hedge a portion of forecasted inventory purchases not\ndenominated in the subsidiaries’ functional currencies. The\nCompany typically hedges portions of its forecasted foreign\ncurrency exposure associated with revenue and inventory purchases\ngenerally up to six months.\n\nTo help protect\nthe net investment in a foreign operation from adverse changes in\nforeign currency exchange rates, the Company may enter into foreign\ncurrency forward and option contracts to offset the changes in the\ncarrying amounts of these investments due to fluctuations in\nforeign currency exchange rates.\n\nThe Company may\nalso enter into foreign currency forward and option contracts to\npartially offset the foreign currency exchange gains and losses\ngenerated by the re-measurement of certain assets and liabilities\ndenominated in non-functional currencies. However, the Company may\nchoose not to hedge certain foreign currency exchange exposures for\na variety of reasons including, but not limited to, accounting\nconsiderations and the prohibitive economic cost of hedging\nparticular exposures. There can be no assurance the hedges will\noffset more than a portion of the financial impact resulting from\nmovements in foreign currency exchange rates.\n\nThe Company\nrecords all derivatives on the Consolidated Balance Sheets at fair\nvalue. The Company’s accounting policies for these\ninstruments are based on whether the instruments are designated as\nhedge or non-hedge instruments. The effective portions of cash flow\nhedges are recorded in AOCI until the hedged item is recognized in\nearnings. The effective portions of net investment hedges are\nrecorded in other comprehensive income as a part of the cumulative\ntranslation adjustment. The ineffective portions of cash flow\nhedges and net investment hedges are recorded in other income and\nexpense. Derivatives that are not designated as hedging instruments\nare adjusted to fair value through earnings in the financial\nstatement line item the derivative relates to.\n\nThe Company had\na net deferred gain associated with cash flow hedges of\napproximately $290 million and a net deferred loss associated with\ncash flow hedges of approximately $252 million, net of taxes,\nrecorded in AOCI as of September\xa024, 2011 and\nSeptember\xa025, 2010, respectively. Deferred gains and losses\nassociated with cash flow hedges of foreign currency revenue are\nrecognized as a component of net sales in the same period as the\nrelated revenue is recognized, and deferred gains and losses\nrelated to cash flow hedges of inventory purchases are recognized\nas a component of cost of sales in the same period as the related\ncosts are recognized. Substantially all of the Company’s\nhedged transactions as of September\xa024, 2011 are expected to\noccur within six months.\n\nDerivative\ninstruments designated as cash flow hedges must be de-designated as\nhedges when it is probable the forecasted hedged transaction will\nnot occur in the initially identified time period or within a\nsubsequent two-month time period. Deferred gains and losses in AOCI\nassociated with such derivative instruments are reclassified\nimmediately into other income and expense. Any subsequent changes\nin fair value of such derivative instruments are reflected in other\nincome and expense unless they are re-designated as hedges of other\ntransactions. The Company did not recognize any significant net\ngains or losses related to the loss of hedge designation on\ndiscontinued cash flow hedges during 2011, 2010 and\n2009.\n\nThe\nCompany’s unrealized net gains and losses on net investment\nhedges, included in the cumulative translation adjustment account\nof AOCI, were not significant as of September\xa024, 2011 and\nSeptember\xa025, 2010, respectively. The ineffective portions and\namounts excluded from the effectiveness test of net investment\nhedges are recorded in other income and expense.']
['Comprehensive Income (Loss), Policy', 'Comprehensive\nIncome\n\nComprehensive\nincome consists of two components, net income and other\ncomprehensive income. Other comprehensive income refers to revenue,\nexpenses, gains and losses that under GAAP are recorded as an\nelement of shareholders’ equity but are excluded from net\nincome. The Company’s other comprehensive income consists of\nforeign currency translation adjustments from those subsidiaries\nnot using the U.S. dollar as their functional currency, unrealized\ngains and losses on marketable securities classified as\navailable-for-sale, and net deferred gains and losses on certain\nderivative instruments accounted for as cash flow\nhedges.']

['- DefinitionDisclosure of accounting policy for advertising costs. For those costs that cannot be capitalized, discloses whether such costs are expensed as incurred or the first period in which the advertising takes place. For direct response advertising costs that are capitalized, describes those assets and the accounting policy used, including a description of the qualifying activity, the types of costs capitalized and the related amortization period. ["- DefinitionDisclosure of accounting policy for cash and cash equivalents, including the policy for determining which items are treated as cash equivalents. Other information that may be disclosed includes (1) the nature of any restrictions on the entity's use of its cash and cash equivalents, (2) whether the entity's cash and cash equivalents are insured or expose the entity to credit risk, (3) the classification of any negative balance accounts (overdrafts), and (4) the carrying basis of cash equivalents (for example, at cost) and whether the carrying amount of cash equivalents approximates fair value.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 235 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 3 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6367646&loc=d3e18780-107790Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 95 -Paragraph 7, 8, 9, 10 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['- DefinitionDisclosure of accounting policy for its derivative instruments and hedging activities. Disclosure may include: (1) Each method used to account for derivative financial instruments and derivative commodity instruments ("derivatives"); (2) the types of derivatives accounted for under each method; (3) the criteria required to be met for each accounting method used, including a discussion of the criteria required to be met for hedge or deferral accounting and accrual or settlement accounting (for example, whether and how risk reduction, correlation, designation, and effectiveness tests are applied); (4) the accounting method used if the criteria specified for hedge accounting are not met; (5) the method used to account for termination of derivatives designated as hedges or derivatives used to affect directly or indirectly the terms, fair values, or cash flows of a designated item; (6) the method used to account for derivatives when the designated item matures, is sold, is extinguished, or is terminated. In addition, the method used to account for derivatives designated to an anticipated transaction, when the anticipated transaction is no longer likely to occur; and (7) where and when derivatives, and their related gains or losses are reported in the statement of financial position, cash flows, and results of operations and (8) an accounting policy decision to offset fair value amounts with counterparties. An entity may also describe its embedded derivatives, and the method(s) used to determine the fair values of derivatives and any significant assumptions used in such valuations.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 815 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 1 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6935481&loc=SL5579240-113959Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher SEC -Name Regulation S-X (SX) -Number 210 -Section 08 -Paragraph n -Article 4Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 815 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 7 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6935481&loc=d3e41675-113959Reference 4: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name FASB Interpretation (FIN) -Number 39 -Paragraph 10 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ["- DefinitionDisclosure of accounting policy for revenue recognition. If the entity has different policies for different types of revenue transactions, the policy for each material type of transaction is generally disclosed. If a sales transaction has multiple element arrangements (for example, delivery of multiple products, services or the rights to use assets) the disclosure may indicate the accounting policy for each unit of accounting as well as how units of accounting are determined and valued. The disclosure may encompass important judgment as to appropriateness of principles related to recognition of revenue. The disclosure also may indicate the entity's treatment of any unearned or deferred revenue that arises from the transaction.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 235 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 1 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6367646&loc=d3e18726-107790Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 605 -SubTopic 10 -Section S99 -Paragraph 1 -Subparagraph (SAB TOPIC 13.B.Q1) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6600647&loc=d3e214044-122780Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher AICPA -Name Accounting Principles Board Opinion (APB) -Number 22 -Paragraph 8, 12, 13 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['- DefinitionTangible assets that are held by an entity for use in the production or supply of goods and services, for rental to others, or for administrative purposes and that are expected to provide economic benefit for more than one year; net of accumulated depreciation. Examples include land, buildings, and production equipment. ['- DefinitionRepresents the noncurrent portion of deferred tax liabilities, which result from applying the applicable tax rate to net taxable temporary differences pertaining to each jurisdiction to which the entity is obligated to pay income tax. A noncurrent taxable temporary difference is a difference between the tax basis and the carrying amount of a noncurrent asset or liability in the financial statements prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. In a classified statement of financial position, an enterprise separates deferred tax liabilities and assets into a current amount and a noncurrent amount. Deferred tax liabilities and assets are classified as current or noncurrent based on the classification of the related asset or liability for financial reporting. A deferred tax liability or asset that is not related to an asset or liability for financial reporting, including deferred tax assets related to carryforwards, are classified according to the expected reversal date of the temporary difference.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 740 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 9 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6907571&loc=d3e31958-109318Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 109 -Paragraph 41, 42 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009. ['Sep. 24, 2011']
['Components of Gross and Net Intangible Asset Balances', 'The following\ntable summarizes the components of gross and net intangible asset\nbalances as of September\xa024, 2011 and September\xa025, 2010\n(in millions):\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2011\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n2010\n\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nGross\nCarrying\nAmount\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nAccumulated\nAmortization\n\xa0\n\xa0\nNet\nCarrying\nAmount\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nGross\nCarrying\nAmount\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\nAccumulated\nAmortization\n\xa0\n\xa0\nNet\nCarrying\nAmount\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\nDefinite lived and\namortizable acquired intangible ["- DefinitionThe aggregate total costs related to selling a firm's product and services, as well as all other general and administrative expenses. Direct selling expenses (for example, credit, warranty, and advertising) are expenses that can be directly linked to the sale of specific products. Indirect selling expenses are expenses that cannot be directly linked to the sale of specific products, for example telephone expenses, Internet, and postal charges. ["- DefinitionNet of tax effect change in accumulated gains and losses from derivative instruments designated and qualifying as the effective portion of cash flow hedges after taxes. A cash flow hedge is a hedge of the exposure to variability in the cash flows of a recognized asset or liability or a forecasted transaction that is attributable to a particular risk. The change includes an entity's share of an equity investee's increase or decrease in deferred hedging gains or losses. While for technical reasons this element has no balance attribute, the default assumption is a credit balance consistent with its label.+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (FAS) -Number 133 -Paragraph 31, 46 -LegacyDoc This reference is SUPERSEDED by the Accounting Standards Codification effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009.
